verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:13
verses.text: )  Aurelius the Bishop said: You, most blessed brethren, remember that after the day fixed for the synod we discussed many things while we were waiting for our brethren who now have been sent as delegates and have arrived at the present synod, which must be placed in the acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:14
verses.text: Wherefore let us render thanks to our Lord for the gathering together of so great an assembly.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:15
verses.text: It remains that the acts of the Nicene Synod which we now have, and have been determined by the fathers, as well as those things enacted by our predecessors here, who confirmed that same Synod, or which according to the same form have been usefully enacted by all grades of the clergy, from the highest even to the lowest, should be brought forward.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:16
verses.text: The whole Council said: Let them be brought forward.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:17
verses.text: Daniel the Notary read: The profession of faith or statutes of the Nicene Synod are as follows.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:18
verses.text: And while he was speaking, Faustinus, a bishop of the people of Potentia, of the Italian province of Picenum, a legate of the Roman Church said: There have been entrusted to us by the Apostolic See certain things in writings, and certain other things as in ordinances to be treated of with your blessedness as we have called to memory in the acts above, that is to say, concerning the canons made at Nice, that their decrees and customs be observed; for some things are observed out of decree and canon, but some from custom.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:19
verses.text: Concerning these things therefore in the first place let us make enquiry, if it please your blessedness; and afterwards let the other ordinances which have been adopted or proposed be confirmed; so that you may be able to show by your rescripts to the Apostolic See, and that you may declare to the same venerable Pope, that we have diligently remembered these things; although the headings of action taken had been already inserted in the acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:20
verses.text: In this matter we should act, as I have said above, as shall please your beloved blessedness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:21
verses.text: Let, therefore the commonitorium come into the midst, that ye may be able to recognize what is contained in it, so that an answer can be given to each point.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:22
verses.text: Aurelius said: Let the commonitorium be brought forward, which our brethren and fellow-ministers lately placed in the acts, and let the rest of the things done or to be done, follow in order.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:23
verses.text: Daniel the Notary read the Commonitorium.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:24
verses.text: To our brother Faustinus and to our sons, the presbyters Philip and Asellus, Zosimus, the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:25
verses.text: You well remember that we committed to you certain businesses, and now [we bid you] carry out all things as if we ourselves were there (for), indeed, our presence is there with you; especially since ye have this our commandment, and the words of the canons which for greater certainty we have inserted in this our commonitory.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:26
verses.text: For thus said our brethren in the Council of Nice when they made these decrees concerning the appeals of bishops:  "But it seemed good that if a bishop had been accused, etc".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:27
verses.text: [Here follows verbatim Canon v.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:28
verses.text: of Sardica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:29
verses.text: ]  Ancient Epitome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:30
verses.text: If bishops shall have deposed a bishop, and if he appeal to the Roman bishop, he should be benignantly heard, the Roman bishop writing or ordering.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:31
verses.text: And when this had been read, Alypius, bishop of the Tagastine Church, and legate of the province of Numidia, said: On this matter there has been some legislation in former sessions of our council, and we profess that we shall ever observe what was decreed by the Nicene Council; yet I remember that when we examined the Greek copies of this Nicene Synod, we did not find these the words quoted—Why this was the case, I am sure I do not know.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:32
verses.text: For this reason we beg your reverence, holy Pope Aurelius, that, as the authentic record of the decrees of the Council of Nice are said to be preserved in the city of Constantinople, you would deign to send messengers with letters from your Holiness, and not only to our most holy brother the bishop of Constantinople, but also to the venerable bishops of Alexandria and Antioch, who shall send to us the decrees of that council with the authentification of their signatures, so that hereafter all ambiguity should be taken away, for we failed to find the words cited by our brother Faustinus; notwithstanding this however we promise to be ruled by them for a short time, as I have already said, until reliable copies come to hand.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:33
verses.text: Moreover the venerable bishop of the Roman Church, Boniface, should be asked likewise to be good enough to send messengers to the aforementioned churches, who should have the same copies according to his rescript, but the copies of the aforementioned Nicene Council which we have, we place in these Acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:34
verses.text: Faustinus the bishop, legate of the Roman Church, said: Let not your holiness do dishonour to the Roman Church, either in this matter or in any other, by saying the canons are doubtful, as our brother and fellow-bishop Alypius has vouchsafed to say: but do you deign to write these things to our holy and most blessed pope, so that he seeking out the genuine canons, can treat with your holiness on all matters decreed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:35
verses.text: But it suffices that the most blessed bishop of the city of Rome should make enquiry just as your holiness proposes doing on your part, that there may not seem to have arisen any contention between the Churches, but that ye may the rather be enabled to deliberate with fraternal charity, when he has been heard from, what is best should be observed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:36
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: In addition to what is set down in the acts, we, by the letters from our insignificance, must more fully inform our holy brother and fellow-bishop Boniface of everything which we have considered.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:37
verses.text: Therefore if our plan pleases all, let us be informed of this by the mouth of all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:38
verses.text: And the whole council said: It seems good to us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:39
verses.text: Novatus the bishop, legate of Mauritania Sitifensis, said: We now call to mind that there is contained in this commonitory something about presbyters and deacons, how they should be tried by their own bishops or by those adjoining, a provision which we find nothing of in the Nicene Council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:40
verses.text: For this cause let your holiness order this part to be read.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:41
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: Let the place asked for be read.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:42
verses.text: Daniel the notary read as follows: Concerning the appeals of clergymen, that is of those of inferior rank, there is a sure answer of this very synod, concerning which thing what ye should do, we think should be inserted, as follows:  "Hosius the bishop said: I should not conceal what has come into my mind up to this time.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:43
verses.text: If any bishop perchance has been quickly angered (a thing what should not happen) and has acted quickly or sharply against a presbyter or a deacon of his, and has wished to drive him out of the Church, provision should be made that the innocent be not condemned, or be deprived of communion: he that has been ejected should have the right of appeal to the bishops of the bordering dioceses, that his case should be heard, and it should be carried on all the more diligently because to him who asks a hearing it should not be denied.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:44
verses.text: And the bishop who either justly or unjustly rejected him, should patiently allow the affair to be discussed, so that his sentence be either approved or else emended, etc".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:45
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:46
verses.text: Ancient Epitome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:47
verses.text: A presbyter or deacon who has been cut off, has the privilege of appealing to the neighbouring bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:48
verses.text: Moreover, he who cut him off should bear with equanimity the conclusion arrived at.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:49
verses.text: This is the first part of Canon xiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:50
verses.text: of Sardica, as the canon previously quoted is Canon v.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:51
verses.text: of the same synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:52
verses.text: And when this had been read, Augustine, the bishop of the Church of Hippo of the province of Numidia, said: We promise that this shall be observed by us, provided that upon more careful examination it be found to be of the Council of Nice.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:53
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:54
verses.text: If this also is pleasing to the charity of you all, give it the confirmation of your vote.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:55
verses.text: The whole Council said: Everything that has been ordained by the Nicene Council pleases us all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:56
verses.text: Jocundus, the bishop of the Church of Suffitula, legate of the province of Byzacena, said: What was decreed by the Nicene Council cannot in any particular be violated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:57
verses.text: Faustinus the bishop, legate of the Roman Church, said: So far as has developed by the confession of your holiness as well as of the holy Alypius, and of our brother Jocundus, I believe that some of the points have been made weak and others confirmed, which should not be the case, since even the very canons themselves have been brought into question.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:58
verses.text: Therefore, that there may be harmony between us and your blessedness, let your holiness deign to refer the matter to the holy and venerable bishop of the Roman Church, that he may be able to consider whether what St.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:59
verses.text: Augustine vouchsafed to enact, should be conceded or not, I mean in the matter of appeals of the inferior grade.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:60
verses.text: If therefore there still is doubt, on this head it is right that the bishop of the most blessed see be informed, if this can be found in the canons which have been approved.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:61
verses.text: Ancient Epitome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:62
verses.text: Since the written decrees of the Nicene Council have not been found, let the Roman bishop deign to write to the bishop of Constantinople and to him of Alexandria, and let us know what he receives from them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:63
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: As we have suggested to your charity, pray allow the copies of the statutes of the Nicene Council to be read and inserted in the acts, as well as those things what have been most healthfully defined in this city by our predecessors, according to the rule of that council, and those which now have been ordained by us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:64
verses.text: And the whole council said: The copies of the Creed, and the statutes of the Nicene Synod which formerly were brought to our council through Caecilean of blessed memory, the predecessor of your holiness (who was present at it), as well as the copies of the decrees made by the Fathers in this city following them, or which now we have decreed by our common consultation, shall remain inserted in these ecclesiastical acts, so that (as has been already said) your blessedness may vouchsafe to write to those most venerable men of the Church of Antioch, and of that of Alexandria, and also of that of Constantinople, that they would send most accurate copies of the decrees of the Council of Nice under the authentification of their signatures, by which, the truth of the matter having become evident, those chapters which in the commonitory our brother who is present, and fellow-bishop Faustinus, as well as our fellow-presbyters Philip and Asellus brought with them, if they be found therein, may be confirmed by us; or if they be not found, we will hold a synod and consider the matter further.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:65
verses.text: Daniel the notary read the profession of faith of the Council of Nice and its statutes to the African Council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:66
verses.text: The Profession of Faith of the Nicene Council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:67
verses.text: We believe in one God, etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:68
verses.text: ,…and in the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:69
verses.text: But those who say, etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:70
verses.text: ,…anathematize them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:71
verses.text: The statutes also of the Nicene Council in twenty heads were likewise read, as are found written before.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:72
verses.text: Then what things were promulgated in the African Synods, were inserted in the present acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:73
verses.text: Canon I.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:74
verses.text: That the statutes of the Nicene Council are to be scrupulously observed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:75
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: Such are the statutes of the Nicene Council, which our fathers at that time brought back with them: and preserving this form, let these things which follow, adopted and confirmed by us, be kept firm.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:76
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:77
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon I.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:78
verses.text: Let the copies of the decrees of the Nicene Council which our fathers brought back with them from that synod, be observed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:79
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:80
verses.text: It is certain that Caecilian, then Bishop of Carthage, was present at the Council of Nice; that any other African bishop was there does not appear; but probably he was attended with several clergyman, who were afterwards ordained bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:81
verses.text: Canon II.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:82
verses.text: Of Preaching the Trinity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:83
verses.text: The whole Council said: By the favour of God, by a unanimous confession the Church's faith which through us is handed down should be confessed in this glorious assembly before anything else; then the ecclesiastical order of each is to be built up and strengthened by the consent of all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:84
verses.text: That the minds of our brethren and fellow bishops lately elevated may be strengthened, those things should be propounded which we have certainly received from our fathers, as the unity of the Trinity, which we retain consecrated in our senses, of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost, which has no difference, as we say, so we shall instruct the people of God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:85
verses.text: Moreover by all the bishops lately promoted it was said: So we openly confess, so we hold, so we teach, following the Evangelic faith and your teaching.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:86
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:87
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon II.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:88
verses.text: No difference is recognised or taught by the decrees of the Council of Nice between the Persons of the Holy Trinity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:89
verses.text: This canon, or rather introduction, is taken from Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:90
verses.text: , of the Council of Carthage held under Genethlius, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:93
verses.text: Canon III.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:94
verses.text: Of Continence.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:95
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: When at the past council the matter on continency and chastity was considered, those three grades, which by a sort of bond are joined to chastity by their consecration, to wit bishops, presbyters, and deacons, so it seemed that it was becoming that the sacred rulers and priests of God as well as the Levites, or those who served at the divine sacraments, should be continent altogether, by which they would be able with singleness of heart to ask what they sought from the Lord: so that what the apostles taught and antiquity kept, that we might also keep.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:96
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:97
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon III.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:98
verses.text: Let a bishop, a presbyter, and a deacon be chaste and continent.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:99
verses.text: This canon is taken from Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:100
verses.text: , of Carthage 387 or 390.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:101
verses.text: Canon IV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:102
verses.text: Of the different orders that should abstain from their wives.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:103
verses.text: Faustinus, the bishop of the Potentine Church, in the province of Picenum, a legate of the Roman Church, said: It seems good that a bishop, a presbyter, and a deacon, or whoever perform the sacraments, should be keepers of modesty and should abstain from their wives.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:104
verses.text: By all the bishops it was said: It is right that all who serve the altar should keep pudicity from all women.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:105
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:106
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon IV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:107
verses.text: Let those who pray abstain from their wives that they may obtain their petitions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:108
verses.text: This canon is taken from Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:109
verses.text: , of Carthage 387 or 390, last mentioned.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:110
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:111
verses.text: See Canon XXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:112
verses.text: "Abstain from their wives," i-e: Some time before and after the Eucharist, as the old Scholiasts understand it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:113
verses.text: [i-e: the Greek scholiasts, but see notes to Canon xiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:114
verses.text: of Quinisext.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:115
verses.text: ]      Canon V.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:116
verses.text: Of Avarice.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:117
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: The cupidity of avarice (which, let no one doubt, is the mother of all evil things), is to be henceforth prohibited, lest anyone should usurp another's limits, or for gain should pass beyond the limits fixed by the fathers, nor shall it be at all lawful for any of the clergy to receive usury of any kind.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:118
verses.text: And those new edicts (suggestiones) which are obscure and generally ambiguous, after they have been examined by us, will have their value fixed (formam accipiunt); but with regard to those upon which the Divine Scripture hath already most plainly given judgment, it is unnecessary that further sentence should be pronounced, but what is already laid down is to be carried out.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:119
verses.text: And what is reprehensible in laymen is worthy of still more severe censure in the clergy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:120
verses.text: The whole synod said: No one hath gone contrary to what is said in the Prophets and in the Gospels with impunity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:121
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:122
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon V.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:123
verses.text: As the taking of any kind of usury is condemned in laymen, much more is it condemned in clergymen.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:124
verses.text: This canon is made up of Canons x.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:125
verses.text: and xiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:126
verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage held under Gratus in a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:127
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:129
verses.text: This synod was held to return thanks for the ending of the Donatist schism; and indeed for some time the evil did seem to have been removed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:130
verses.text: Donatist worship was prohibited by the imperial law and it was not until the times of Constans and Constantius that it again openly asserted itself.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:131
verses.text: The synod while in session also took advantage of the opportunity of passing some useful general canons on discipline.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:132
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:133
verses.text: See Canon of the Apostles 36 (44); Nic.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:135
verses.text: Canon VI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:136
verses.text: That the chrism should not be made by presbyters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:137
verses.text: Fortunatus the bishop, said: In former councils we remember that it was decreed that the chrism or the reconciliation of penitents, as also the consecration of virgins be not done by presbyters: but should anyone be discovered to have done this, what ought we to decree with regard to him?  Aurelius the bishop said: Your worthiness has heard the suggestion of our brother and fellow-bishop Fortunatus; What answer will you give?  And all the bishops replied: Neither the making of the chrism, nor the consecration of virgins, is to be done by presbyters, nor is it permitted to a presbyter to reconcile anyone in the public mass (in publica missa), this is the pleasure of all of us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:138
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:139
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon VI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:140
verses.text: Let no presbyter make the chrism, nor prepare the unction, nor consecrate virgins, nor publicly reconcile anyone to communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:141
verses.text: This is Canon iij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:142
verses.text: of the Carthaginian Synod under Genethlius, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:143
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:145
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:146
verses.text: Not the chrism used upon persons at their baptism, says the scholion in Bishop Beveridge's Annotation, but the Mystical Chrism, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:147
verses.text: , that used at Confirmation; though neither was the chrism used at baptism to be consecrated by Priests.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:148
verses.text: See Decr.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:149
verses.text: of Gelasius 6.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:150
verses.text: Du Pin observes, That this is one of the first monuments where the name of "mass" occurs to signify the public prayers, which the church made at offering the Eucharist.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:151
verses.text: And let the reader observe, that there is no mention of the "mass" in the copies which the Greeks made use of.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:152
verses.text: And further, he restrains the meaning of the word "mass" too much, when he supposes that it denoted the Communion Office only.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:153
verses.text: Canon VII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:154
verses.text: Concerning those who are reconciled in peril of death.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:155
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: If anyone had fallen into peril of death during the absence of the bishop, and had sought to reconcile himself to the divine altars, the presbyter should consult the bishop, and so reconcile the sick man at his bidding, which thing we should strengthen with healthy counsel.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:156
verses.text: By all the bishops it was said: Whatever your holiness has taught us to be necessary, that is our pleasure.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:157
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:158
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon VII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:159
verses.text: A priest desiring to reconcile anyone in peril to the sacred altars must consult the bishop and do what seems good to him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:160
verses.text: This is Canon iv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:161
verses.text: of the Synod of 387 or 390.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:162
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:163
verses.text: See Canon 43.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:164
verses.text: Canon VIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:165
verses.text: Of those who make accusation against an elder; and that no criminal is to be suffered to bring a charge against a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:166
verses.text: Numidius, the bishop of Maxula, said: Moreover, there are very many, not of good life, who think that their elders or bishops should be the butt for accusation; ought such to be easily admitted or no? Aurelius the bishop said: Is it the pleasure of your charity that he who is ensnared by divers wickednesses should have no voice of accusation against these?  All the bishops said: If he is criminous, his accusation is not to be received.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:167
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:168
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon VIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:169
verses.text: It has seemed good that they who are themselves defendants for crimes should not bring accusations; nor should they be allowed to lay crimes to anyone's charge.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:170

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:263
verses.text: Moreover it seemed good that if any bishop, presbyter, or deacon, who had a criminal charge brought against him or who had a civil cause, refused to be tried by the ecclesiastical tribunal, but wished to be judged by the secular courts, even if he won his suit, nevertheless he should lose his office.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:265

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:364

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:365
verses.text: )  That if any bishop is accused the cause should be brought before the primate of his own province.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:366
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: Whatever bishop is accused the accuser shall bring the case before the primates of the province to which the accused belongs, and he shall not be suspended from communion by reason of the crime laid to his charge unless he fails to put in an appearance on the appointed day for arguing his cause before the chosen judges, having been duly summoned by the letters; that is, within the space of one month from the day in which he is found to have received the letters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:367
verses.text: But should he be able to prove any true necessity which manifestly rendered it impossible for him to appear, he shall have the opportunity of arguing his case within another full month; but after the second month he shall not communicate until he is acquitted.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:368
verses.text: But if he is not willing to come to the annual general council, so that his cause may there be terminated, he himself shall be judged to have pronounced the sentence of his own condemnation at the time in which he does not communicate, nor shall he communicate either in his own church or diocese.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:369
verses.text: But his accuser, if he has not missed any of the days for pleading the cause, shall not be shut out from communion; but if he has missed some of them, withdrawing himself, then the bishop shall be restored to communion and the accuser shall be removed from communion; so, nevertheless, that the possibility of going on with the case be not taken from him, if he shall prove that his absence was caused by lack of power and not by lack of will.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:370
verses.text: And this is enacted, that if the accuser turn out to be himself a criminal when the case against the bishop has come to argument, he shall not be allowed to testify unless he asserts that the causes are personal and not ecclesiastical.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:561
verses.text: It also seemed good that presbyters, deacons, and others of the inferior clergy in the causes which they had, if they were dissatisfied with the judgments of their bishops, let the neighbouring bishops with the consent of their own bishop hear them, and let the bishops who have been called in judge between them: but if they think they have cause of appeal from these, they shall not betake themselves to judgments from beyond seas, but to the primates of their own provinces, or else to an universal council, as has also been decreed concerning bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:654
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: After the day fixed for the council, as ye remember, most blessed brethren, we sat and waited for the legations of all the African provinces to assemble upon the day, as I have said, set by our missive; but when the letter of our Byzacene bishops had been read, that was read to your charity, which they had discussed with me who had anticipated the time and day of the council; also it was read by our brethren Honoratus and Urban, who are to-day present with us in this council, sent as the legation of the Sitifensine Province.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:655

verses.text: That holy virgins when they are separated from their parents by whom they have been wont to be guarded, are to be commended by the care of the bishop, or presbyter where the bishop is absent, to women of graver age, so that living with them they may take care of them, lest they hurt the reputation of the Church by wandering about.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:825
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:826
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:827
verses.text: She who leaves her father for the sake of virginity is to be commended to grave women.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:828
verses.text: This canon is Canon xxxj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:829
verses.text: of the Synod of Hippo, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:830
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:832
verses.text: Canon XLV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:833
verses.text: (Greek xlviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:834
verses.text: )  Concerning those who are sick and cannot answer for themselves.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:835
verses.text: That the sick are to be baptized who cannot answer for themselves if their [servants] shall have spoken at their own proper peril a testimony of the good will [of the sick man].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:836
verses.text: (Greek Canon xlix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:837
verses.text: )  Concerning players who are doing penance and are converted to the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:838
verses.text: That to players and actors and other persons of that kind, as also to apostates when they are converted and return to God, grace or reconciliation is not to be denied.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:839
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:840
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:841
verses.text: That he who cannot answer for himself on account of illness is to be baptized when he shall have given evidence of his desire.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:842
verses.text: A repentant actor is to be received to penance.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:843
verses.text: This canon is made up of Canons xxxij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:844
verses.text: and xxxiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:845
verses.text: of the Synod of Hippo, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:846
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:848
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:849
verses.text: "Apostates," i-e:, those who elsewhere are called Lapsi; those who had done sacrifice through the violence of torment in time of persecution, professing in the meantime that their consciences did not consent to what their hands did.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:850
verses.text: Canon XLVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:851
verses.text: (Greek l.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:852
verses.text: )  Concerning the passions of the martyrs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:853
verses.text: The passions of the Martyrs may be read when their anniversary days are celebrated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:854
verses.text: Note.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:855
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:856
verses.text: The passions of the martyrs are to be read on their commemorations.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:857
verses.text: This canon is the last part of Canon xxxvj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:858
verses.text: of the Synod of Hippo, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:859
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:861
verses.text: Canon XLVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:862
verses.text: (Greek li.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:863
verses.text: )  Concerning [the Donatists and] the children baptized by the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:864
verses.text: Concerning the Donatists it seemed good that we should hold counsel with our brethren and fellow priests Siricius and Simplician concerning those infants alone who are baptized by Donatists: lest what they did not do of their own will, when they should be converted to the Church of God with a salutary determination, the error of their parents might prevent their promotion to the ministry of the holy altar.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:865
verses.text: But when these things had been begun, Honoratus and Urbanus, bishops of Mauritania Sitifensis, said: When some time ago we were sent to your holiness, we laid aside what things had been written on this account, that we might wait for the arrival of our brethren the legates from Numidia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:866
verses.text: But because not a few days have passed in which they have been looked for and as yet they are not arrived, it is not fitting that we should delay any longer the commands we received from our brother-bishops; and therefore, brethren, receive our story with alacrity of mind.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:867
verses.text: We have heard concerning the faith of the Nicene tractate: True it is that sacrifices are to be forbidden after breakfast, so that they may be offered as is right by those who are fasting, and this has been confirmed then and now.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:868
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:869
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:870
verses.text: When those in infancy baptized by Donatists are converted, this shall be no impediment to them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:871
verses.text: And the Holy Mysteries, as is right, are to be celebrated only by them fasting.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:872
verses.text: This canon is made from Canon xxxvij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:873
verses.text: of the Synod of Hippo, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:874
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:875
verses.text: 393, and from Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:876
verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage of August 28th, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:877
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:879
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:880
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:882
verses.text: The pretence that the Donatists had for making a schism was, that Caecilian, Bishop of Carthage, had, in the time of persecution, been a Traditor, i-e:, given up the Bible to the heathen inquisitors; this was denied by the Orthodox, who charged them with the same crime in effect, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:883
verses.text: of being too favourable to the Traditors, and those that had lapsed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:884
verses.text: They likewise are charged with Arianism.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:885
verses.text: I have omitted what is here mentioned concerning the Council of Nice; because I do not find that any one has been able to penetrate into the meaning of the Fathers as to that particular.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:886
verses.text: Canon XLVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:887
verses.text: (Greek lii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:888
verses.text: )  Of rebaptisms, reordinations, and translations of bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:889
verses.text: But we suggest that we decree what was set forth by the wisdom of the plenary synod at Capua, that no rebaptisings, nor reordinations should take place, and that bishops should not be translated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:890
verses.text: For Cresconius, bishop of Villa Regis, left his own people and invaded the Church of Tubinia and having been admonished down to this very day, to leave, according to the decree, the diocese he had invaded, he treated the admonition with disdain.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:891
verses.text: We have heard that the sentence pronounced against him has been confirmed; but we seek, according to our decree, that ye deign to grant that being driven thereto by necessity, it be free to us to address the rector of the province against him, according to the statutes of the most glorious princes, so that whoever is not willing to acquiesce in the mild admonition of your holiness and to amend his lawlessness, shall be immediately cast out by judicial authority.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:892
verses.text: Aurelius the bishop said: By the observance of the constituted form, let him not be judged to be a member of the synod, if he has been asked by you, dear brethren, to depart and has refused: for out of his own contempt and contumacy he has fallen to the power of the secular magistrate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:893
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban the bishops said: This pleases us all, does it not? And all the bishops answered: It is just, it pleases us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:894
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:895
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:896
verses.text: Let there be no rebaptisms, nor reordinations nor translations of bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:897
verses.text: Therefore let Cresconius be forbidden by judicial authority, for he has left his own people, and has taken possession of the diocese of Ceneum, although ecclesiastically admonished that he was not to change.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:898
verses.text: This canon is Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:899
verses.text: , of the Synod of Carthage of August 28th.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:900
verses.text: a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:901
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:903
verses.text: The acts of this synod were first accurately edited by the Ballerini (in their edition of the works of St.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:904
verses.text: Leo) and were printed by Mansi, in an amended form, in his Concilia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:905
verses.text: Canon XLIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:906
verses.text: (Greek liii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:907
verses.text: )  How many bishops there should be to ordain a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:908
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: We have issued this command, that (because lately two of our brethren, bishops of Numidia, presumed to ordain a pontiff,) only by the concurrence of twelve bishops the ordination of bishops be celebrated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:909
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: The ancient form shall be preserved, that not less than three suffice who shall have been designated for ordaining the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:910
verses.text: Moreover, because in Tripoli, and in Arzug the barbarians are so near, for it is asserted that in Tripoli there are but five bishops, and out of that number two may be occupied by some necessity; but it is difficult that all of the number should come together at any place whatever; ought this circumstance to be an impediment to the doing of what is of utility to the Church? For in this Church, to which your holiness has deigned to assemble we frequently have ordinations and nearly every Lord's day; could I frequently summon twelve, or ten, or about that number of bishops? But it is an easy thing for me to join a couple of neighbours to my littleness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:911
verses.text: Wherefore your charity will agree with me that this cannot be observed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:912
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:913
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XLIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:914
verses.text: Fewer than three bishops do not suffice for the ordination of a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:915
verses.text: This is Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:916
verses.text: , of the Synod of Carthage, August 28th, 397.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:917
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:918
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:920
verses.text: The occasion of this canon was a complaint that two bishops in Numidia had presumed to ordain a third; upon which it was proposed that not less than twelve should perform this office: But Aurelius, Bishop of Carthage, desires that the old form might be observed, and three bishops be sufficient; especially, because in Tripoli, where there were but five bishops in all, it would be hard to get more than three together.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:921
verses.text: And he adds, that though it were no hard matter for him to get two bishops to assist him in his ordinations at Carthage, yet it would not be practicable for him to get twelve: "For," says he, "we have frequently, and almost every Sunday, men to be ordained".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:922
verses.text: He must mean bishops for otherwise it had been nothing to his purpose, because he could ordain priests or deacons by himself, without the assistance of other bishops: and yet it is very strange, that ordinations of bishops should be so frequent as to bear that expression of "almost every Sunday".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:923
verses.text: There were indeed above one hundred bishoprics in his Province; but these could not occasion above six or eight ordinations in a year; but it is probable that the privilege belonging to him, Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:924
verses.text: 55, brought very many ordinations to the church of Carthage; for it is evident, there was a great scarcity of men fit for the Episcopal office in Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:925
verses.text: It is further evident from this canon, that bishops were not ordained in the church of their own see, but in that of the Primate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:926
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:927
verses.text: Ant.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:929
verses.text: Canon L.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:930
verses.text: (Greek liv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:931
verses.text: )  How many bishops should be added to the number of those ordaining, if any opposition had been made to the one to be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:932
verses.text: But this should be decreed, that when we shall have met together to choose a bishop, if any opposition shall arise, because such things have been treated by us, the three shall not presume to purge him who was to be ordained, but one or two more shall be asked to be added to the aforesaid number, and the persons of those objecting shall first be discussed in the same place (plebe) for which he was to be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:933
verses.text: And last of all the objections shall be considered; and only after he has been cleared in the public sight shall he at last be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:934
verses.text: If this agrees with the mind of your holiness, let it be confirmed by the answer of your worthiness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:935
verses.text: All the bishops said, We are well pleased.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:936
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:937
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon L.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:938
verses.text: If any controversy arise concerning a bishop who has been elected by three bishops, let two others be coöpted, and so let there be an examination made of his affairs; and if it shall appear that he is pure, let him be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:939
verses.text: This canon is Canon iij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:940
verses.text: , of the Synod of Carthage, Aug.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:942
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:943
verses.text: Here the bishops meet to choose a new one, and it is evident by the foregoing canon, that they met not in the vacant church, but in that of the Primate; and that therefore not the people, but the bishops had the chief share in the election.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:944
verses.text: The people might make their objections, which supposes they knew who their intended bishop was; but the bishops were the judges of the cause.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:945
verses.text: And it seems probable, that if there were any dispute, some of the bishops went to the vacant church to hear the allegations against the person that was elected, or proposed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:946
verses.text: Canon LI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:947
verses.text: (Greek lv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:948
verses.text: )  That the date of Easter is to be announced by the Church of Carthage.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:949
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: Since all things treated by our commonitory are known, we add also what has been ordered concerning the day of Easter, that we be informed of the date always by the Church of Carthage, as has been accustomed and that no short time before.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:950
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: If it seems good to your holiness, since we remember that we pledged ourselves sometime ago that every year we would come together for discussion, when we assemble, then let the date of the holy Easter be announced through the legates present at the Council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:951
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: Now we seek of the present assembly that ye deign to inform our province of that day by letters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:952
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: It is necessary it should be so.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:953
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:954
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:955
verses.text: Let the day on which Easter is to be kept be announced by the Church of Carthage in the annual synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:956
verses.text: This canon is the first part of Canon iv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:957
verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage, August 28th, 397.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:958
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:959
verses.text: The synod met in August.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:960
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:962
verses.text: Canon LII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:963
verses.text: (Greek lvi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:964
verses.text: )  Of visiting provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:965
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: This was commanded to us in word, that because it had been decreed in the Council of Hippo that each province should be visited in the time of the council, that ye also deign that this year or next, according to the order ye have drawn up, you should visit the province of Mauritania.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:966
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: Of the province of Mauritania because it is situated in the confines of Africa, we have made no decree, for they are neighbours of the barbarians; but God grant (not however that I make any rash promise of doing so), we may be able to come to your province.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:967
verses.text: For ye should consider, brethren, that this same thing our brethren of Tripoli and of the Arzuges region could demand also, if occasion offered.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:968
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:969
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:970
verses.text: As the Synod at Hippo decreed, every province should be visited in an annual Synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:971
verses.text: This canon is the last part of canon iv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:972
verses.text: of the Council of Carthage, August 28th, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:973
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:975
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:976
verses.text: The manner of visiting provinces, and that annually; and the persons by whom this visitation was performed, can scarce now be discovered; only it appears, by the words of Aurelius, that the Bishop of Carthage was one, if not the only visitor; but it was impossible that he could visit all the provinces in Africa personally every year, he must use delegates.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:977
verses.text: Canon LIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:978
verses.text: (Greek lvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:979
verses.text: )  That dioceses should not receive a bishop except by the consent of its own bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:980
verses.text: Epigonius, the bishop, said: In many councils it has been decreed by the sacerdotal assembly that such communities as are contained in other dioceses and ruled by their bishops, and which never had any bishops of their own, should not receive rulers, that is bishops, for themselves except with the consent of the bishop under whose jurisdiction they have been.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:981
verses.text: But because some who have attained a certain domination abhor the communion of the brethren, or at least, having become depraved, claim for themselves domination with what is really tyranny, for the most part tumid and stolid presbyters, who lift up their heads against their own bishops or else win the people to themselves by feasting them or by malignant persuasion, that they may by unlawful favour wish to place themselves as rulers over them; we indeed hold fast that glorious desire of your mind, most pious brother Aurelius, for thou hast often opposed these things, paying no heed to such petitioners; but on account of their evil thoughts and basely conceived designs this I say, that such a community, which has always been subject in a diocese, ought not to receive a rector, nor should it ever have a bishop of its own.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:982
verses.text: Therefore if this which I have proposed seems good to the whole most holy council, let it be confirmed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:983
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: I am not in opposition to the proposition of our brother and fellow bishop: but I confess that this has been and shall be my practice concerning those who were truly of one mind, not only with regard to the Church of Carthage, but concerning every sacerdotal assemblage.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:984
verses.text: For there are many who, as has been said, conspire with the people whom they deceive, tickling their ears and blandly seducing them, men of vicious lives, or at least puffed up and separated from this meeting, who think to watch over their own people, and never come to our council for fear that their wickedness should be discussed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:985
verses.text: I say, if it seems good, that not only should these not keep their dioceses, but that every effort should be made to have them expelled by public authority from that church of theirs which has evilly favoured them, and that they be removed even from the chief sees.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:986
verses.text: For it is right that he who cleaves to all the brethren and the whole council, should possess with full right not only his church but also the dioceses.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:987
verses.text: But they who think that the people suffice them and spurn the love of the brethren, shall not only lose their dioceses, but (as I have said,) they shall be deprived by public authority of their own cures as rebels.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:988
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: The lofty provision of your holiness obtains the adherence of the minds of all of us, and I think that by the answer of all what you have deigned to propose will be confirmed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:989
verses.text: All the bishops said: Placet, placet.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:990
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:991
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:992
verses.text: Whoso shall neglect his call to a synod, and shall despise the charity of his brethren, putting his trust in the multitude who are with him, let him be deprived of them by the imperial authority.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:993
verses.text: This canon is Canon v.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:994
verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage of August 28th, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:995
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:996
verses.text: 397, beginning with the second clause.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:997
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:998
verses.text: It is very evident that a diocese here signifies some town or village lying remote from the Bishop's City, but belonging to his jurisdiction; and is to be understood to be a place distinct from the bishop's church or cathedral.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:999
verses.text: See also Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1000
verses.text: 56 and Decr.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1001
verses.text: Anast.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1003
verses.text: Canon LIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1004
verses.text: (Greek lviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1005
verses.text: )  That a strange cleric is under no circumstances to be received by another.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1006
verses.text: Epigonius, the bishop, said: This has been decreed in many councils, also just now it has been confirmed by your prudence, most blessed brethren, that no bishop should receive a strange cleric into his diocese without the consent of the bishop to whose jurisdiction the cleric belongs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1007
verses.text: But I say that Julian, who is ungrateful for the layouts bestowed upon him by God through my littleness, is so rash and audacious, that a certain man who was baptized by me, when he was a most needy boy, commended to me by the same, and when for many years he had been fed and reared by me, it is certain that this one, as I have said, was baptized in my church, by my own unworthy hands; this same man began to exercise the office of reader in the Mappalien diocese, and read there for nearly two years, with a most incomprehensible contempt of my littleness, the aforenamed Julian took this man, whom he declared to be a citizen of his own city Vazarita, and without consulting me ordained him deacon.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1008
verses.text: If, most blessed brethren, that is permissible, let it be declared to us; but if not, let such an impudent one be restrained that he may in no way mix himself in someone's communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1009
verses.text: Numidius, the bishop, said: If, as it seems, Julian did this without your worthiness being asked for his consent, nor even consulted, we all judge that this was done iniquitously and unworthily.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1010
verses.text: Wherefore unless Julian shall correct his error, and shall return the cleric to your people with proper satisfaction, since what he did was contrary to the decrees of the council, let him be condemned and separated from us on account of his contumacy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1011
verses.text: Epigonius, the bishop, said: Our father in age, and most ancient by his promotion, that laudable man, our brother and colleague Victor wishes that this petition should be made general to all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1012
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1013
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1014
verses.text: Since Julian has ordained a reader of Epigonius's to the diaconate, unless he shall shew authority received from him to do so, he shall increase the penalty of his contumacy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1015
verses.text: This canon is Canon vj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1022
verses.text: (Greek lix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1023
verses.text: )  That it be lawful for the bishop of Carthage to ordain a cleric whenever he wishes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1024
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: My brethren, pray allow me to speak.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1025
verses.text: It often happens that ecclesiastics who are in need seek deacons [praepositis in the Latin], or presbyters or bishops from me: and I, bearing in mind what things have been ordained these I observe, to wit, I summon the bishop of the cleric who is sought for, and I shew him the state of affairs, how that they of a certain church ask for a certain one of his clergy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1026
verses.text: Perchance then they make no objection, but lest it happen that afterwards they might object when in this case they shall have been demanded (postulati) by me, who (as you know) have the care of many churches and of the ordinands.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1027
verses.text: It is right therefore that I should summon a fellow bishop with two or three witnesses from our number.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1028
verses.text: But if he be found indevotus [ἀκαθοσίωτος], what does your charity think should be done? For I, as ye know, brethren, by the condescension of God have the care of all the churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1029
verses.text: Numidius, the bishop, said: This see always had the power of ordaining a bishop according to the desire of each Church as he wills and on whose name there was agreement (fuisset conventus).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1030
verses.text: Epigonius, the bishop, said: Your good nature makes small use of your powers, for you make much less use of them than you might, since, my brother, you are good and gentle to all; for you have the power, but it is far from your practice to satisfy the person of each bishop in prima tantummodo conventione.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1031
verses.text: But if it should be thought that the rights of this see ought to be vindicated, you have the duty of supporting all the churches, wherefore we do not give thee power, but we confirm that power thou hast, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1032
verses.text: : that thou hast the right at thy will always to choose whom thou wilt, to constitute prelates over peoples and churches who shall have asked thee to do so, and when thou so desirest.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1033
verses.text: Posthumianus, the bishop, said: Would it be right that he who had only one presbyter should have that one taken away from him? Aurelius, the bishop, said: But there may be one bishop by whom many presbyters can be made through the divine goodness, but one fit to be made bishop is found with difficulty.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1034
verses.text: Wherefore if any bishop has a presbyter necessary for the episcopate and has one only, my brother, as you have said, even that one he ought to give up for promotion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1035
verses.text: Posthumianus, the bishop, said: If some other bishop has plenty of clergy, should that other diocese come to my help? Aurelius, the bishop, said: Of course, when you have come to the help of another Church, he who has many clerics should be persuaded to make one over to you for ordination.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1036
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1037
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1038
verses.text: It is lawful for the bishop of Carthage, whenever he wills, to choose those who are to be set over the churches: even if there were only one presbyter worth of rule.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1039
verses.text: For one bishop can ordain many presbyters, but one fit for the episcopate is hard to find.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1040
verses.text: This canon is the first half of Canon vij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1045
verses.text: It is evident, that this privilege of the Bishop of Carthage extended to the whole African diocese or the six provinces of Africa, which contained near five hundred bishoprics.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1046
verses.text: This was what caused such frequent ordinations of bishops in the Church of Carthage (See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1047
verses.text: Afr.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1048
verses.text: 49, and the Note).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1049
verses.text: And it is further apparent, that the Bishop of Carthage had some power over the whole African church, and was probably their visitor (See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1051
verses.text: But that he had the sole power of ordaining bishops for every church, with the assistance of any two bishops, does not appear, though Justellus is of this opinion; nay, the 49th canon proves that he had it not.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1052
verses.text: Canon LVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1053
verses.text: (Greek lx.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1054
verses.text: )  That bishops who were ordained for dioceses shall not choose for themselves dioceses [in the Greek provinces].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1055
verses.text: Honoratus and Urban, the bishops, said: We have heard that it has been decreed that dioceses should not be deemed fit to receive bishops, unless with the consent of their founder: but in our province since some have been ordained bishops in the diocese, by the consent of that bishop by whose power they were established, have even seized dioceses for themselves, this should be corrected by the judgment of your charity, and prohibited for the future.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1056
verses.text: Epigonius, the bishop, said: To every bishop should be reserved what is right, so that from the mass of dioceses no part should be snatched away, so as to have its own bishop, without consent from the proper authority.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1057
verses.text: For it shall suffice, if the consent be given, that the diocese thus set apart have its own bishop only, and let him not seize other dioceses, for only the one cut off from the many merited the honour of receiving a bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1058
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: I do not doubt that it is pleasing to the charity of you all, that he who was ordained for a diocese by the consent of the bishop who held the mother see, should retain only the people for whom he was ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1059
verses.text: Since therefore I think that everything has been treated of, if all things are agreeable to your mind, pray confirm them all by your suffrage.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1060
verses.text: All the bishops said: We all are well pleased, and we have confirmed them with our subscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1061
verses.text: And they signed their names.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1062
verses.text: I, Aurelius, bishop of the Church of Carthage, have consented to this decree, and have subscribed what has been read.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1063
verses.text: So too did all the other bishops in like fashion sign.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1064
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1065
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1066
verses.text: If any diocese has received consent to have a bishop of its own from him who has the right, that one shall not invade the rest of the dioceses.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1067
verses.text: This is the last part of Canon vij.

verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage, August 28, a.

verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1072
verses.text: It had scarce been worth while to give so much of this canon in English if I had not thought it proper, in order to confirm the sense of the word diocese, mentioned in note on Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1073
verses.text: 53, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1075
verses.text: Between this canon and the following, there is a reference to a former council at Carthage forbidding bishops to sail, without a formal letter from the Primate; and this said to be done when Caesarius and Atticus were consuls, anno aerae vulg.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1076
verses.text: 397, and there is mention of an embassy of two bishops from a council of Carthage to the Emperors, to procure the privilege of sanctuary to all impeached for any crime, if they fled to the Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1077
verses.text: This is said to be done when Honorius and Eutychianus were consuls, anno aerae vulg.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1079
verses.text: And further, here is an account of a bishop sent legate to Anastasius, Bishop of the Apostolical see, and Venerius of Milan, to supply the African Church with men fit to be ordained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1080
verses.text: For Aurelius complains that many Churches have not so much as one man, not so much as an illiterate one, in deacon's orders, much less had they a competent number of men for the superior dignities.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1081
verses.text: He speaks of the importunate clamours of many people, that were themselves almost killed, I suppose, by some common pestilence.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1082
verses.text: In this council it was decreed that bishops should not travel by sea without formed letters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1083
verses.text: During the consulate of those illustrious men, Caesar and Atticus, on the sixth before the Calends of July, at Carthage, it seemed good that no bishop should travel by water without "formed letters" from the Primate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1084
verses.text: The authentic acts will be found by him who seeks them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1085
verses.text: In this council, bishops whose names are set down hereafter were sent as legates to the Emperor.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1086
verses.text: After the consulate of the most glorious Emperor Honorius Augustus for the fourth time, and of the renowned Eutychian, on the fifth of the calends of May, at Carthage in the secretarium of the restored basilica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1087
verses.text: In this council Epigonius and Vincent, the bishops, received a legation, in order that they might obtain a law from the most glorious princes in behalf of those taking refuge in the Church, whatever might be the crime of which they were accused, that no one should dare to force them away.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1088
verses.text: In this council a legation was sent to the Bishops of Rome and Milan with regard to children baptized by heretics, and to the Emperor with regard to having such idols as still remained taken away, and also with regard to many other matters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1089
verses.text: After the consulate of the renowned Flabius Stilico, on the sixteenth of the calends of July, at Carthage in the secretarium of the restored basilica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1090
verses.text: When Aurelius, the Bishop, together with his fellow-bishops had taken their seats, the deacons standing by, Aurelius, the Bishop, said: Your charity, most holy brethren, knows fully as well as I do the necessities of the churches of God throughout Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1091
verses.text: And since the Lord has vouchsafed that from a part of your holy company this present assembly should be convened, it seems to me that these necessities which in the discharge of our solicitude we have discovered, we ought to consider together.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1092
verses.text: And afterwards, that there should be chosen a bishop from our number who may, with the help of the Lord and your prayers, assume the burden of these necessities, and zealously accomplish whatever ought to be done in the premises, going to the parts of Italy across seas, that he may acquaint our holy brethren and fellow-bishops, the venerable and holy brother Anastasius, bishop of the Apostolic see, and also our holy brother Venerius the Bishop of Milan, with our necessity and grief, and helplessness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1093
verses.text: For there has been withheld from these sees the knowledge of what was necessary to provide against the common peril, especially that the need of clergy is so great that many churches are in such destitution as that not so much as a single deacon or even an unlettered clerk is to be found.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1094
verses.text: I say nothing of the superior orders and offices, because if, as I have said, the ministry of a deacon is not easily to be had, it is certainly much more difficult to find one of the superior orders.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1095
verses.text: [And let them also tell these bishops] that we can no longer bear to hear the daily lamentations of the different peoples almost ready to die, and unless we do our best to help them, the grievous and inexcusable cause of the destruction of innumerable souls will be laid at our door before God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1096
verses.text: Canon LVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1097
verses.text: (Greek lxi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1098
verses.text: )  That persons baptized when children by the Donatists may be ordained clergymen in the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1099
verses.text: Since in the former council it was decreed, as your unanimity remembers as well as I do, that those who as children were baptized by the Donatists, and not yet being able to know the pernicious character of their error, and afterward when they had come to the use of reason, had received the knowledge of the truth, abhorred their former error, and were received, (in accordance with the ancient order) by the imposition of the hand, into the Catholic Church of God spread throughout the world, that to such the remembrance of the error ought to be no impediment to the reception of the clerical office.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1100
verses.text: For in coming to faith they thought the true Church to be their own and there they believed in Christ, and received the sacraments of the Trinity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1101
verses.text: And that all these sacraments are altogether true and holy and divine is most certain, and in them the whole hope of the soul is placed, although the presumptuous audacity of heretics, taking to itself the name of the truth, dares to administer them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1102
verses.text: They are but one after all, as the blessed Apostle tells us, saying: "One God, one faith, one baptism," and it is not lawful to reiterate what once only ought to be administered.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1103
verses.text: [Those therefore who have been so baptized] having anathematized their error may be received by the imposition of the hand into the one Church, the pillar as it is called, and the one mother of all Christians, where all these Sacraments are received unto salvation and everlasting life; even the same sacraments which obtain for those persevering in heresy the heavy penalty of damnation.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1104
verses.text: So that which to those who are in the truth lighteneth to the obtaining of eternal life, the same to them who are in error tends but to darkness and damnation.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1105
verses.text: With regard then to those who, having fled from error, acknowledge the breasts of their mother the Catholic Church, who believe and receive all these holy mysteries with the love of the truth, and besides the Sacraments have the testimony of a good life, there is no one who would not grant that without doubt such persons may be raised to the clerical office, especially in such necessity as the present.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1106
verses.text: But there are others of this sect, who being already clergymen, desire to pass to us with their peoples and also with their honours, such as for the sake of office are converts to life, and that they may retain them seek for salvation [i-e:, enter the Church].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1107
verses.text: I think that the question concerning such may be left to the graver consideration of our aforesaid brothers, and that when they have considered by their more prudent counsel the matter referred to them, they may vouchsafe to advise us what approves itself to them with regard to this question.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1108
verses.text: Only concerning those who as children were baptized by heretics we decree that they consent, if it seems good, to our decision concerning the ordination of the same.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1109
verses.text: All things, therefore, which we have set forth above with the holy bishops, let your honourable fraternity with me adjudge to be done.

verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1112
verses.text: Such as have been while children baptized by the Donatists may be ordained should they repent, anathematize their heresy, and be otherwise worthy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1130
verses.text: )  Of the remaining idols or temples which should be done away by the Emperors.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1131
verses.text: Wherefore the most religious Emperors should be asked that they order the remaining idols to be taken entirely away throughout all Africa; for in many maritime places and in divers possessions the iniquity of this error still flourishes: that they command them to be taken away and their temples, (such as are no ornament, being set up in fields or out of the way places) be ordered to be altogether destroyed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1140
verses.text: (Greek lxiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1141
verses.text: )  That clerics be not compelled to give testimony in public concerning the cognizance of their own judgment.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1142
verses.text: It should be petitioned also that they deign to decree, that if perchance any shall have been willing to plead their cause in any church according to the Apostolic law imposed upon the Churches, and it happens that the decision of the clergy does not satisfy one of the parties, it be not lawful to summon that clergyman who had been cognitor or present, into judgment as a witness, and that no person attached to any ecclesiastic be compelled to give testimony.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1145
verses.text: A cleric who has decided a case shall not, if it be displeasing, be summoned to a tribunal to give evidence concerning it; and no ecclesiastical person shall be forced to give testimony.
