verses.text: Canon LX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1160
verses.text: (Greek lxiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1161
verses.text: )  Of heathen feasts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1162
verses.text: This also must be sought, that (since contrary to the divine precepts feasts are held in many places, which have been induced by the heathen error, so that now Christians are forced to celebrate these by heathens, from which state of things it happens that in the times of the Christian Emperors a new persecution seems to have secretly arisen:) they order such things to be forbidden and prohibit them from cities and possessions under pain of punishment; especially should this be done since they do not fear to commit such iniquities in some cities even upon the natal days of most blessed martyrs, and in the very sacred places themselves.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1163
verses.text: For upon these days, shame to say, they perform the most wicked leapings throughout the fields and open places, so that matronal honour and the modesty of innumerable women who have come out of devotion for the most holy day are assaulted by lascivious injuries, so that all approach to holy religion itself is almost fled from.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1164
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1165
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1166
verses.text: The Greek feasts must cease to be kept, because of their impropriety, and because they seduce many Christians, moreover they are celebrated on the commemorations of the martyrs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1167

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1177
verses.text: (Greek lxiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1178
verses.text: )  Of spectacles, that they be not celebrated on Lord's days nor on the festivals of the Saints.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1179
verses.text: Furthermore, it must be sought that theatrical spectacles and the exhibition of other plays be removed from the Lord's day and the other most sacred days of the Christian religion, especially because on the octave day of the holy Easter [i-e:, Low Sunday] the people assemble rather at the circus than at church, and they should be transferred to some other day when they happen to fall upon a day of devotion, nor shall any Christian be compelled to witness these spectacles, especially because in the performance of things contrary to the precepts of God there should be no persecution made by anyone, but (as is right) a man should exercise the free will given him by God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1180
verses.text: Especially also should be considered the peril of the cooperators who, contrary to the precepts of God, are forced by great fear to attend the shews.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1181

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1191
verses.text: And this should be sought, that they deign to decree that if any clergyman of whatever rank shall have been condemned by the judgment of the bishops for any crime, he may not be defended either by the churches over which he presided, nor by anyone whatever, under pain of loss both of money and office, and let them order that neither age nor sex be received as an excuse.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1202
verses.text: And of them also it must be sought that if anyone wishes to come to the grace of Christianity from any ludicrous art (ludicra arte) and to remain free of that stain, it be not lawful for anyone to induce him or compel him to return to the performance of the same things again.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1213

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1214
verses.text: )  Of celebrating manumissions in church, that permission be asked from the Emperor.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1215
verses.text: Concerning the publishing of manumissions in church, if our fellow bishops throughout Italy shall be found to do this, it will be a mark of our confidence to follow their order [of proceedings], full power being given to the legate we send, that whatever he can accomplish worthy of the faith, for the state of the Church and the salvation of souls, we shall laudably accept in the sight of the Lord.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1216
verses.text: All which things, if they please your sanctity, pray set forth, that I may be assured that my suggestion has been ratified by you and that their sincerity may freely accept our unanimous action.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1217
verses.text: And all the bishops said: The things which have been enjoined to be done and have been wisely set forth by your holiness are pleasing to all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1218
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1220

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1226
verses.text: It is certain, that in Italy, and some other parts of the Empire, slaves were solemnly set at liberty by their masters, in the church and presence of the bishop, from the time of Constantine, but it should seem this custom had not yet obtained in Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1227
verses.text: Canon LXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1228
verses.text: (Greek lxviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1229
verses.text: )  Concerning the condemned bishop Equitius.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1230
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: I do not think that the case of Equitius should be passed over in the legation, who some time ago for his crimes was condemned by an Episcopal sentence; that if by any chance our legate should meet him in those parts, our brother should take care for the state of the Church, as opportunity offered or where he could, to act against him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1231
verses.text: And all the bishops said: This prosecution is exceedingly agreeable to us, especially as Equitius was condemned some time ago, his impudent unrest ought to be repelled everywhere more and more for the good estate and health of the Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1232
verses.text: And they subscribed, I, Aurelius, the bishop of the Church of Carthage, have consented to this decree, and after having read it have signed my name.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1233
verses.text: Likewise also signed all the other bishops.

verses.text: Equitius, who had been condemned by the judgment of the bishops, and had behaved impudently against the ecclesiastical authority, ought to be opposed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1245
verses.text: In this council the letters of Anastasius the Roman Pontiff were read, admonishing the Catholic bishops concerning the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1246
verses.text: In the consulship of those most illustrious men Vencentius and Flavius, on the Ides of September, at Carthage, in the secretarium of the restored basilica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1247
verses.text: When we had been gathered together in council in the church at Carthage and had taken our seats, bishops from all the African Provinces, that is to say, Aurelius, the bishop of that see with his colleagues (just who they were is made evident by their signatures) [the same bishop Aurelius said]: When the letters of our most blessed brother and fellow priest, Anastasius, bishop of the Church of Rome, had been read, in which he exhorted us out of the solicitude and sincerity of his paternal and brotherly love, that we should in no way dissimulate with regard to the wiles and wickednesses of the Donatist heretics and schismatics, by which they gravely vex the Catholic Church of Africa, we thank our Lord that he hath vouchsafed to inspire that best and holy archbishop with such a pious care for the members of Christ, although in divers lands, yet builded together into the one body of Christ.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1248
verses.text: Canon LXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1249
verses.text: (Greek lxix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1250
verses.text: )  That the Donatists are to be treated leniently.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1251
verses.text: Then when all things had been considered and treated of which seem to conduce to the advantage of the church, the Spirit of God suggesting and admonishing us, we determined to act leniently and pacifically with the before-mentioned men, although they were cut off from the unity of the Lord's body by an unruly dissent, so that (as much as in us lies) to all those who have been caught in the net of their communion and society, it might be known throughout all the provinces of Africa, how they have been overcome by miserable error, holding different opinions, "that perchance," as the Apostle says, when we have corrected them with gentleness, "God should grant them repentance for the acknowledging of the truth, and that they might be snatched out of the snares of the devil, who are led captive of him at his will".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1252
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1253
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1254
verses.text: It seemed good that the Donatists should be treated kindly and with leniency, even if they should separate themselves from the Church, so that perchance through their respect for our great gentleness they may be loosed from their captivity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1255
verses.text: The introduction refers to the Synod of Carthage of September 13, 401, and this canon is part of Canon j.

verses.text: of that Synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1257
verses.text: We are indebted to the Ballerini for collecting the acts of this Synod by a comparison of the pseudo-Isidore, Dionysius, Ferrandus and the quotations contained in the acts of the Synod of Carthage of 525.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1258
verses.text: Canon LXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1259
verses.text: (Greek lxx.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1260
verses.text: )  Of the letters to be sent to the judges, that they may take note of the things done between the Donatists and the Maximianists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1261
verses.text: Therefore it seemed good that letters should be given from our council to the African judges, from whom it would seem suitable that this should be sought, that in this matter they would aid the common mother, the Catholic Church, that the episcopal authority may be fortified in the cities; that is to say that by their judicial power and with diligence out of their Christian faith, they enquire and record in the public acts, that all may have a firm notion of it, what has taken place in all those places in which the Maximianists, who made a schism from them, have obtained basilicas.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1262
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1263
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1264
verses.text: The secular arm must be implored by synodal letters to assist our common Mother the Catholic Church against those by whom the authority of the bishop is despised.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1265
verses.text: This canon is the other half of Canon j.

verses.text: Maximianists were a sect bred out of the Donatists, and separating from them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1271
verses.text: Canon LXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1272
verses.text: (Greek lxxi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1273
verses.text: )  That the Donatist clergy are to be received into the Catholic Church as clergymen.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1274
verses.text: It moreover seemed good that letters be sent to our brethren and fellow-bishops, and especially to the Apostolic See, over which our aforesaid venerable brother and colleague Anastasius, presides, that [ἐπειδὴ in the Greek, quo in the Latin] he may know that Africa is in great need, for the peace and prosperity of the Church, that those Donatists who were clergymen and who by good advice had desired to return to Catholic unity, should be treated according to the will and judgment of each Catholic bishop who governs the Church in that place; and, if it seem good for Christian peace, they be received with their honours, as it is clear was done in the former times of this same division.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1275
verses.text: And that this was the case the example of the majority, yea, of nearly all the African Churches in which this error had sprung up, testify; not that the Council which met about this matter in foreign parts should be done away, but that it may remain in force with regard to those who so will to come over to the Catholic Church that there be procured by them no breaking of unity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1276
verses.text: But those through whom Catholic unity was seen to have been altogether perfected or assisted by the manifest winning of the souls of their brethren in the places where they live, there shall not be objected to them the decree contrary to their honour adopted by a foreign council, for salvation is shut off to no one, that is to say, that those ordained by the Donatist party, if having been corrected they have been willing to return to the Catholic Church, are not to be received in their grades, according to the foreign council; but they are to be excepted through whom they received the advice to return to Catholic unity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1277
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1278
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1279
verses.text: Those ordained by the Donatists, even though their reception has been forbidden by a foreign synod, since it is truly good that all should be saved, if they correct themselves, let them be received.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1280
verses.text: Balsamon.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1281
verses.text: This canon is special, for it seemed good to the fathers that such of the Donatists as came to the orthodox faith should be so received as to hold the grade of their holy orders, even though a transmarine, that is to say an Italian, council had decreed otherwise.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1282
verses.text: Aristenus.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1283
verses.text: Those Donatists who are penitent and anathematize their heresy are to be allowed to remain in their proper rank, and be numbered among the clergy of the Catholic Church, because Africa was labouring under a great shortness of clergy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1284
verses.text: This canon is Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1285
verses.text: of Carthage, Sept.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1287
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1289
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1290
verses.text: Whether the Donatists' clergy should be re-ordained was only a point of discipline; for the Donatists retained Episcopacy.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1291
verses.text: Therefore the African fathers, as they leave other churches to their liberty, so at the same time they declare that they would continue their old practice, and leave every bishop to act according to his own discretion in this matter.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1292
verses.text: Probably, one great motive, besides that of peace, which they had to this, was the great scarcity of clergymen in Africa, of which Aurelius complains in his speech, inserted into the Acts before Canon 77 (61), and proposes that they send to the bishops of Rome and Milan for a supply.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1293
verses.text: And that this was the true reason, does in some measure appear from the words of the Latin canon at large, in which the occasion of this decree is said to be propter necessitatem.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1294
verses.text: And this is the most probable reason why it is left to the discretion of the bishop, whether to admit Donatist clergymen as such, if he had occasion for their service.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1295
verses.text: And after all it is clear from this very canon, that other churches had determined this point the contrary way.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1296
verses.text: Therefore Mr.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1297
verses.text: Calamy exceeds when he says: "As for the Donatists, all agree that their orders were acknowledged".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1298
verses.text: Further, he would have it thought probable that orders were not always conferred among the Donatists by persons superior to presbyters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1299
verses.text: This he would infer from the great number of the bishops of that faction in Africa, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1300
verses.text: , 278, many of which (says he) could be no more than parish ministers.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1301
verses.text: But why so? Were there not above four hundred Catholic bishops? And why not as many of one side as the other? If our dissenters of any sort had fallen into the Episcopal form of government, no question but they would have had a bishop in every city at least, and equalled our church in the number of prelates.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1302
verses.text: Canon LXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1303
verses.text: (Greek lxxii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1304
verses.text: )  That a legation be sent to the Donatists for the sake of making peace.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1305
verses.text: It further seemed good, that when these things were done, legates should be sent from our number to those of the Donatists whom they hold as bishops, or to the people, for the sake of preaching peace and unity, without which Christian salvation cannot be attained; and that these legates should direct the attention of all to the fact that they have no just objection to urge against the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1306
verses.text: And especially that this be made manifest to all by the municipal acts (on account of the weight of their documents) what they themselves had done in the case of the Maximianists, their own schismatics.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1307
verses.text: For in this case it is shown them by divine grace, if they will but heed it, that their separation from the unity of the Church is as iniquitous as they now proclaim the schism of the Maximianists from themselves to be.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1308
verses.text: Nevertheless from the number, those whom they condemned by the authority of their plenary council, they received back with their honours, and accepted the baptism which they had given while condemned and cut off.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1309
verses.text: And thus let them see how with stupid heart they resist the peace of the Church scattered throughout the whole world, when they do these things on the part of Donatus, neither do they say that they are contaminated by communion with those whom they so receive for the making of peace, and yet they despise us, that is the Catholic Church, which is established even in the extreme parts of the earth, as being defiled by the communion of those whom the accusers have not been able to win over to themselves.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1310
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1311
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1312
verses.text: It seemed good that legates be sent to preach peace and unity to the Donatists who had been converted to the orthodox faith.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1318

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1319
verses.text: )  What clerics should abstain from their wives.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1320
verses.text: Moreover since incontinence has been charged against some clergymen with regard to their own wives it has seemed good that bishops, presbyters, and deacons should according to the statutes already made abstain even from their own wives; and unless they do so that they should be removed from the clerical office.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1321
verses.text: But the rest of the clergy shall not be forced to this but the custom of each church in this matter shall be followed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1322
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1323

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1324
verses.text: Bishops, presbyters and deacons shall abstain for their wives or else be removed from the ecclesiastical order.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1325
verses.text: But the rest of the clergy shall not be forced to the same: but let the custom be observed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1334
verses.text: )  Of those who leave in neglect their own people.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1335
verses.text: Moreover it seemed good that no one should be allowed to leave his chief cathedral and go to another church built in the diocese, or to neglect the care and frequent attendance upon his own cathedral by reason of too great care for his own affairs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1336
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1337

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1338
verses.text: It seemed good that no bishop shall translate himself to another see, leaving his own, nor that through a care for his own affairs he should neglect his diocese.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1347
verses.text: (Greek lxxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1348
verses.text: )  Of the baptism of infants when there is some doubt of their being already baptized.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1349
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that whenever there were not found reliable witnesses who could testify that without any doubt they were baptized and when the children themselves were not, on account of their tender age, able to answer concerning the giving of the sacraments to them, all such children should be baptized without scruple, lest a hesitation should deprive them of the cleansing of the sacraments.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1350
verses.text: This was urged by the Moorish Legates, our brethren, since they redeem many such from the barbarians.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1351
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1352

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1353
verses.text: It seemed good that they should be baptized about whom there was an ambiguity whether they had been baptized or no; lest they might through that doubt lose the divine ablution.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1360
verses.text: )  The date of Easter and the date of the Council should be announced.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1361
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that the day of the venerable Easter should be intimated to all by the subscription of formed letters; and that the same should be observed with regard to the date of the Council, according to the decree of the Council of Hippo, that is to say the X.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1362
verses.text: Calends of September, and that it should be written to the primates of each province so that when they summon their councils they do not impede this day.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1365

verses.text: )  That no bishop who is an intercessor is to hold the see where he is intercessor.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1378
verses.text: Item, it has been decreed that it is not lawful to any intercessor to retain the see to which he has been appointed as intercessor, by any popular movements and seditions; but let him take care that within a year he provide them with a bishop: but if he shall neglect to do so, when the year is done, another intercessor shall be appointed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1379
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1380
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1381
verses.text: It seemed good that the bishop who had been called in as an intercessor, by the zeal and dissensions of the people, should not be allowed to become the occupant of its throne: but let a bishop be provided within a year, or else in the next year let another intercessor be appointed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1382
verses.text: This is Canon IX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1383
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1384
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1386
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1387
verses.text: We here call this officer "Guardian of the spiritualities" in the vacancy of the see.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1388
verses.text: Canon LXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1389
verses.text: (Greek lxxviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1390
verses.text: )  Of asking from the Emperors defenders of the Churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1391
verses.text: On account of the afflictions of the poor by whose troubles the Church is worn out without any intermission, it seemed good to all that the Emperors be asked to allow defenders for them against the power of the rich to be chosen under the supervision of the bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1392
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1393
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1394
verses.text: That the bishop be not annoyed, let Defensors be appointed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1395
verses.text: This is Canon X.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1396
verses.text: of Carthage, September, 401.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1397
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1398
verses.text: See note on Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1399
verses.text: Chalcedon, 23.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1400
verses.text: Canon LXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1401
verses.text: (Greek lxxix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1402
verses.text: )  Of bishops who do not put in an appearance at Council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1403
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that as often as the council is to be assembled, the bishops who are impeded neither by age, sickness, or other grave necessity, come together, and that notice be given to the primates of their several provinces, that from all the bishops there be made two or three squads, and of each of these squads there be elected some who shall be promptly ready on the council day: but should they not be able to attend, let them write their excuses in the tractory, or if after the coming of the tractory certain necessities suddenly arise by chance, unless they send to their own primate an account of their impediment, they ought to be content with the communion of their own Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1404
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1405
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1406
verses.text: Those who do not attend the annual synod, unless they be involuntarily prevented, must be satisfied with the communion of their own churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1407
verses.text: This is Canon xj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1408
verses.text: , of Carthage, September, 401.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1409
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1410
verses.text: "Tractory" has several significations; here it seems to denote the written return made by the Primate of the province to the synodical letter sent by the Bishop of Carthage.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1411
verses.text: In the acts inserted between canon 90th and 91st "Tractoria" seems to denote the letter of the Primate to the inferior bishops for choosing legates, if it do not rather denote the Bishop of Carthage's circular-letter to all the primates, as it does in the next paragraph.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1412
verses.text: [The penalty in the last clause is] a very singular sort of censure, and very moderate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1413
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1415
verses.text: Canon LXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1416
verses.text: (Greek lxxx.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1417
verses.text: )  Of Cresconius.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1418
verses.text: Concerning Cresconius of Villa Regis this seemed good to all, that the Primate of Numidia should be informed on this matter so that he should by his letters summon the aforementioned Cresconius in order that at the next plenary Council of Africa he should not put off making an appearance.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1419
verses.text: But if he contemns the summons and does not come, let him recognize the fact that sentence should be pronounced against him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1420
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1421
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1422
verses.text: Unless Cresconius who has been summoned by letter to the Synod, shall appear, let him know that he will have sentence given against him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1423
verses.text: This canon was probably formerly an appendix (so Hefele thinks) to Canon xj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1424
verses.text: , of the Synod of Carthage of September 13, 401.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1425
verses.text: Canon LXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1426
verses.text: (Greek lxxxi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1427
verses.text: )  Of the Church of Hippo-Diarrhytus.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1428
verses.text: It further seemed good that since the destitution of the Church of Hippo-Diarrhytus should no longer be neglected, and the churches there are retained by those who have declined the infamous communion of Equitius, that certain bishops be sent from the present council, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1429
verses.text: : Reginus, Alypius, Augustine, Maternus, Theasius, Evodius, Placian, Urban, Valerius, Ambivius, Fortunatus, Quodvultdeus, Honoratus, Januarius, Aptus, Honoratus, Ampelius, Victorian, Evangelus and Rogation; and when those had been gathered together, and those had been corrected who with culpable pertinacity were of opinion that this flight of the same Equitius should be waited for, let a bishop be ordained for them by the vote of all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1430
verses.text: But if these should not be willing to consider peace, let them not prevent the choosing for ordination of a bishop, for the advantage of the church which has been so long destitute.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1431
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1432
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1433
verses.text: It seemed good that, after Equitius had been condemned by the universal vote, a bishop of Hippo should be elected, and that they should in no way impede the ordination of a prelate for that church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1434
verses.text: This canon was likewise probably an appendix, to Canon xiij, of the Synod of Carthage of September 13th, 401, according to Hefele.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1435
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1436
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1437
verses.text: Afr.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1439
verses.text: Here the place of election and consecration seems to be the vacant see.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1440
verses.text: Canon LXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1441
verses.text: (Greek lxxxii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1442
verses.text: )  Of clerics who do not take care to have their causes argued within a year.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1443
verses.text: It was further decreed that as often as clergymen convicted and confessed of any crime either on account of eorum, quorum verecundiae parcitur, or on account of the opprobrium to the Church, and of the insolent glorying of heretics and Gentiles, if perchance they are willing to be present at their cause and to assert their innocence, let them do so within one year of their excommunication; if in truth they neglect during a year to purge their cause, their voice shall not be heard afterwards.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1444
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1445
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1446
verses.text: When a cleric has been convicted of a crime, if he says his cause should be heard upon appeal, let the appeal be made within a year; after that the appeal shall not be admitted.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1447
verses.text: This is Canon xiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1448
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1449
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1451
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1452
verses.text: Though the Latin syntax of this canon is very confused, and, I am apt to think, corrupted, yet it is evident enough, that this is the intention of it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1453
verses.text: Canon LXXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1454
verses.text: (Greek lxxxiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1455
verses.text: )  That it is not permitted to make superiors of monasteries nor to ordain as clerics those who are received from a monastery not one's own.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1456
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that if any bishop wished to advance to the clericature a monk received from a monastery not under his jurisdiction, or shall have appointed him superior of a monastery of his own, the bishop who shall have thus acted shall be separated from the communion of others and shall rest content with the communion of his own people alone, but the monk shall continue neither as cleric nor superior.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1457
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1458
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1459
verses.text: Whoever shall receive a monk from a monastery not subject to his jurisdiction, and if he shall ordain him to the clerical estate or shall appoint him prior of his monastery, such an one shall be cut off from communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1460
verses.text: This is Canon xiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1461
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1462
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1464
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1465
verses.text: See Canons 76 (79) and 122 (123).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1466
verses.text: Canon LXXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1467
verses.text: (Greek lxxxiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1468
verses.text: )  Of bishops who appoint heretics or heathens as their heirs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1469
verses.text: Item, it was ordained that if any bishop should prefer to his Church strangers to blood relationship with him, or his heretical relatives, or pagans as his heirs, he shall be anathematized even after his death, and his name shall by no means be recited among those of the priests of God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1470
verses.text: Nor can he be excused if he die intestate, because being a bishop he was bound not to postpone making such a disposition of his goods as was befitting his profession.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1471
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1472
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1473
verses.text: Let a bishop be anathema if he make heretics and heathen his heirs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1474
verses.text: This is Canon xv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1475
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1476
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1478
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1479
verses.text: There were in this age two written tables kept in every church, whereof one contained the names of all eminent bishops and clergymen now living, with whom that church held communion and correspondence; the other, the names of all eminent bishops, and other men of their own or other churches, now dead.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1480
verses.text: The deacon rehearsed all the names, in both tables at the altar, whenever the Eucharist was celebrated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1481
verses.text: These tables were by the Greeks called Δίπτυχα, and by some English writers "diptychs".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1482
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1483
verses.text: of Peter of Alex.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1485
verses.text: Canon LXXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1486
verses.text: (Greek lxxxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1487
verses.text: )  Of manumissions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1488
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that the Emperor be petitioned with regard to announcing manumissions in church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1489
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1490
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1491
verses.text: The imperial permission must be asked for the making of the manumission of slaves in churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1492
verses.text: Aristenus.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1493
verses.text: This is the same as the sixty-fourth [Greek numbering] canon, and is there explained.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1494
verses.text: This is Canon xvj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1495
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1496
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1498
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1499
verses.text: A repetition of Canon 64 (67).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1500
verses.text: Canon LXXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1501
verses.text: (Greek lxxxvi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1502
verses.text: )  Of false Memories of Martyrs.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1503
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that the altars which have been set up here and there, in fields and by the wayside as Memories of Martyrs, in which no body nor reliques of martyrs can be proved to have been laid up, should be overturned by the bishops who rule over such places, if such a thing can be done.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1504
verses.text: But should this be impossible on account of the popular tumult it would arouse, the people should none the less be admonished not to frequent such places, and that those who believe rightly should be held bound by no superstition of the place.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1505
verses.text: And no memory of martyrs should at all be accepted, unless where there is found the body or some reliques, on which is declared traditionally and by good authority to have been originally his habitation, or possession, or the scene of his passion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1506
verses.text: For altars which have been erected anywhere on account of dreams or inane quasi-revelations of certain people, should be in every way disapproved of.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1507
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1508
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1509
verses.text: An altar in the fields or in a vineyard which lacks the reliques of the martyrs should be thrown down unless it would cause a public tumult to do so: and the same is the case with such as have been set up on account of dreams and false revelations.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1510
verses.text: This is Canon xvij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1511
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1512
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1514
verses.text: Canon LXXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1515
verses.text: (Greek lxxxvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1516
verses.text: )  Of extirpating the remains of the idols.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1517
verses.text: Item, it seemed good to petition the most glorious Emperors that the remains of idolatry not only in images, but in any places whatever or groves or trees, should altogether be taken away.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1518
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1519
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1520
verses.text: Let all remains of idolatry be abolished whether in statues, or in places, or groves or trees.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1521
verses.text: This is Canon xviij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1522
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1523
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1525
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1526
verses.text: See Canon 58 (62.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1527
verses.text: )      Canon LXXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1528
verses.text: (Greek lxxxviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1529
verses.text: )  That by the bishop of Carthage, when there shall be need, letters shall be written and subscribed in the name of all the bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1530
verses.text: It was said by all the bishops: If any letters are to be composed in the name of the council it seemed good that the venerable bishop who presides over this See should vouchsafe to dictate and sign them in the name of all, among which also are those to the episcopal legates, who are to be sent throughout the African provinces, in the matter of the Donatists; and it seemed good that the letters given them should contain the tenor of the mandate which they are not to go beyond.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1531
verses.text: And they subscribed: I, Aurelius, bishop of the church of Carthage have consented to this decree and having read it have signed it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1532
verses.text: Likewise all the rest of the bishops subscribed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1533
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1534
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1535
verses.text: It seemed good that whatever letters were to be sent from the Synod should be written and subscribed by the bishop of Carthage in the name of all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1536
verses.text: This is Canon xix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1537
verses.text: of Carthage, September, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1538
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1540
verses.text: In this Council previous decrees are confirmed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1541
verses.text: In the fifth consulate of the most glorious Emperors Arcadius and Honorius, Augusti, the VI Calends of September, in the City of Milevis, in the secretarium of the basilica, when Aurelius the bishop of Carthage had taken his seat in plenary council, the deacons standing by, Aurelius, the bishop, said: Since the body of the holy Church is one, and there is one head of all the members, it has come to pass by the divine permission and assistance given to our weakness, that we, invited out of brotherly love, have come to this church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1542
verses.text: Wherefore I beg your charity to believe that our coming to you is neither superfluous, nor unacceptable to all; and that the consent of all of us may make it manifest that we agree with the decrees already confirmed by the Council at Hippo or which were defined afterwards by a larger synod at Carthage, these shall now be read to us in order.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1543
verses.text: Then at last the agreement of your holiness will appear clearer than light, if they know that the things lawfully defined by us in former councils, ye have set forth, not only by your consent to these acts, but also by your subscriptions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1544
verses.text: Xantippus, bishop of the first see of Numidia said: I believe what pleased all the brethren and the statutes they confirmed with their hands; we by our subscribing our names shew that it pleases us also, and have confirmed them with our superscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1545
verses.text: Nicetius, the bishop of the first see of Mauritania Sitifensis said: The decrees which have been read, since they do not lack reason, and have been approved by all, these also are pleasing to my littleness, and I will confirm them with my subscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1546
verses.text: Canon LXXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1547
verses.text: (Greek lxxxix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1548
verses.text: )  Of the order of bishops, that those ordained more recently do not dare to take precedence of those ordained before them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1549
verses.text: Valentine, the bishop, said: If your good patience will permit, I follow the things which were done in time past in the Church of Carthage, and which were illustrious having been confirmed by the subscriptions of the brethren, and I profess that we intend to preserve this.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1550
verses.text: For this we know, that ecclesiastical discipline has always remained inviolate: therefore let none of the brethren dare to place himself before those ordained earlier than himself; but by the offices of charity this has always been shewn to those ordained earlier, which always should be accepted joyfully by those ordained more recently.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1551
verses.text: Let your holiness give command that this order be strengthened by your interlocutions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1552
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: It would not be fitting that we should repeat these things, were it not for the existence of certain inconsiderate minds, which would induce us to making such statutes; but this is a common cause about which our brother and fellow bishop has spoken, that each one of us should recognize the order decreed to him by God, and that the more recent should defer to the earlier ordained, and they should presume to do nothing when these have not been consulted.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1553
verses.text: Wherefore I say, now that I think of it, that they who think they may presume to take precedence over those ordained before them, should be coerced suitably by the great council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1554
verses.text: Xantippus, bishop of the first see of Numidia, said: All the brethren present have heard what our brother and fellow bishop Aurelius has said, what answer do we make? Datian, the bishop, said: The decrees made by our ancestors should be strengthened by our assent, so that the action taken by the Church of Carthage in past synods should hold fast, being confirmed by the full assent of all of us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1555
verses.text: And all the bishops said: This order has been preserved by our fathers and by our ancestors, and shall be preserved by us through the help of God, the rights of the primacy of Numidia and of Mauritania being kept intact.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1556
verses.text: Of the archives and matricula of Numidia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1557
verses.text: Moreover it seemed good to all the bishops who subscribed in this council that the matricula and the archives of Numidia should be at the first see and in the Metropolis, that is Constantina.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1558
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1559
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1560
verses.text: Thou shalt not prefer thyself to thine elders, but shalt follow them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1561
verses.text: For he that spurns those who were before him should be frowned down upon.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1562
verses.text: The introduction belongs to the Synod of Milevis, of August 27, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1563
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1565
verses.text: This canon (lxxxvj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1566
verses.text: ) is Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1567
verses.text: , of the above named Synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1568
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1569
verses.text: From this canon it appears that the primacy in Africa was ambulatory, and belonged to the senior bishop of the province.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1570
verses.text: If the primacy had been fixed to the bishop of any certain city, as in other countries, there would have been a salvo or exception for that bishop, as there is in the 24th canon of the Synod of Bracara [Braga] in Spain, which orders that all bishops take place according to their seniority, with a reserve to the bishop of the metropolis.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1571
verses.text: The bishop of Carthage was not included in this canon; for it is evident that he had a precedence annexed to his see, and that he was in reality a sort of patriarch.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1572
verses.text: The reason why Numidia and Mauritania are particularly mentioned is, that some disputes had been started there on that subject.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1573
verses.text: Canon LXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1574
verses.text: (Greek xc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1575
verses.text: )  Concerning Quodvultdeus, the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1576
verses.text: In the case of Quodvultdeus of Centuria, it pleased all the bishops that no one should communicate with him until his cause should be brought to a conclusion, for his accuser when he sought to bring the cause before our council, upon being asked whether he was willing with him to be tried before the bishops, at first said that he was, but on another day answered that he was not willing, and went away.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1577
verses.text: Under these circumstances to deprive him of his bishoprick, before the conclusion of his cause was known, could commend itself to no Christian as a just act.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1578
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1579
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1580
verses.text: Since Quodvultdeus at first promised to come to our synod when his opposer had asked that he be admitted, and afterwards withdrew, saying that that was displeasing to him, he should be excommunicated, until the cause is finished.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1581
verses.text: But it is not just that he be deposed before sentence is given.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1582
verses.text: This canon is part of Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1583
verses.text: of Synod of Milevis, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1584
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1586
verses.text: Canon LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1587
verses.text: (Greek xci.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1588
verses.text: )  Of Maximian, the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1589
verses.text: But in the case of Maximian of Vagai it seemed good that letters be sent from the council both to him and to his people; that he should vacate the bishoprick, and that they should request another to be appointed for them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1590
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1591
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1592
verses.text: Let Maximian of Bagai be expelled from his church, and another be set in his room.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1593
verses.text: This canon is remaining part of Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1594
verses.text: , of the Synod of Milevis, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1595

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1597
verses.text: Canon LXXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1598
verses.text: (Greek xcii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1599
verses.text: )  That bishops who are ordained shall receive letters from their ordainers bearing the date and the name of the consul.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1600
verses.text: It further seemed good that whoever thereafter should be ordained by the bishops throughout the African provinces, should receive from their ordainers letters, written in their own hands, containing the name of the consul and the date, that no altercation might arise concerning which were ordained first and which afterwards.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1601
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1602
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon LXXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1603
verses.text: Whoever is ordained in Africa let him have letters signed by the proper hand of him that ordained him, containing the date and the name of the Consul.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1604
verses.text: This is Canon iij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1605
verses.text: of Milevis, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1606
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1608
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1609
verses.text: It is evident from this canon that the church in this age followed the date of the civil government, which was in the consulship of Caius and Titius, as our civil date is in the 1st, 2d, 3d, etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1610
verses.text: , year of the reign of our King or Queen.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1611
verses.text: Canon XC.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1612
verses.text: (Greek xciii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1613
verses.text: )  Of those who have once read in church, that they cannot be advanced by others.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1614
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that whoever in church even once had read should not be admitted to the ministry (clericatum) by another church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1615
verses.text: And they subscribed: I, Aurelius, bishop of the Church of Carthage, have consented to this decree, and, having read it, have signed it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1616
verses.text: Likewise also the rest of the bishops signed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1617
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XC.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1618
verses.text: He who has only once read in a Church [i-e:, diocese] shall not be admitted into the clergy by another Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1619
verses.text: This is Canon iv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1620
verses.text: of Milevis, 402.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1621
verses.text: There is set forth in this council what the bishops did who were sent as legates across seas.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1622
verses.text: In the consulship of those most illustrious men, the most glorious Emperor Theodosius Augustus, and Rumoridus, the VIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1623
verses.text: Calends of September, at Carthage, in the basilica of the second region, when Aurelius the bishop had taken his seat in plenary council, the deacons standing by, Aurelius, the bishop, said: From stress of circumstances, venerable brethren, I, although so small, have been led to assemble you in council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1624
verses.text: For a while ago, as your holinesses will remember, while holding a council we sent our brothers as legates to the regions beyond seas.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1625
verses.text: It is right that these should at this meeting of your holinesses narrate the course of their now finished legation, and although yesterday when we were in session concerning this matter, besides ecclesiastical matters, we paid some prolonged attention to what they had done, nevertheless it is right that to-day the discussion of yesterday should be confirmed by ecclesiastical action.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1626
verses.text: Of the bishops of the African provinces who were not present at this council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1627
verses.text: The right order of things demands that first of all we should enquire concerning our brethren and fellow bishops, who were to come to this council either from Byzacena or at least from Mauritania, like as they decreed that they would be present in this council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1628
verses.text: And when Philologius, Geta, Venustianus, and Felician, bishops of the province of Byzacena had presented and read their letters of legation, and Lucian and Silvanus, legates of the province of Mauritania Sitiphensis, had done the same, the bishop Aurelius said: Let the text of these writings be placed in the acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1629
verses.text: Of the Byzacene bishops.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1630
verses.text: Numidius, the bishop, said: We observe that our brethren and fellow bishops of the province of Byzacena and of the province of Mauritania Sitiphensis have sent legates to the council; we now seek whether the legates of Numidia have come, or at least of the province of Tripoli or of Mauritania-Caesariensis.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1631
verses.text: Of the bishops of Mauritania Sitiphensis.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1632
verses.text: Lucian and Silvanus, the bishops, legates of the Province of Mauritania Sitiphensis said: The tractory came late to our Caesarian brethren or they would have been here; and they will certainly come, and we are confident of their attitude of mind that whatever shall be determined by this council, they without doubt will assent unto.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1633
verses.text: Of the bishops of Numidia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1634
verses.text: Alypius, bishop of the church of Tagaste said: We have come from Numidia, I and the holy brethren Augustine and Possidius, but a legation could not be sent from Numidia, because by the tumult of the recruits the bishops have either been prevented from coming or fully occupied by their own necessary affairs in their sees.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1635
verses.text: For after I had brought to the holy Senex Xantippus your holiness's tractory, this seemed good in the present business that a council should be appointed, to which a delegation with instructions should be sent, but when I reported to him in later letters the impediment of the recruits, of which I have just spoken, he excused them by his own rescripts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1636
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: There is no doubt that the aforesaid brethren and bishops of Numidia, when they shall have received the acts of the council, will give their consent and will take pains to carry into effect whatever shall have been adopted.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1637
verses.text: It is therefore necessary that by the solicitude of this see what we shall have determined be communicated to them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1638
verses.text: Of the bishops of Tripoli.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1639
verses.text: This is what I could learn concerning our brethren of Tripoli, that they appointed our brother Dulcicius as a legate: but because he could not come, certain of our sons coming from the aforesaid province asserted that the aforesaid had taken shipping, and that it was thought that his arrival had been delayed by storms; nevertheless also concerning these matters, if your charity is willing, this form shall be preserved, that the placets of the council be sent to them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1640
verses.text: And all the bishops said: What your holiness has decreed pleases us all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1641
verses.text: Canon XCI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1642
verses.text: (Greek xciv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1643
verses.text: )  Of holding meetings with the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1644
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: What has come out in the handling of your charity, I think this should be confirmed by ecclesiastical acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1645
verses.text: For the profession of all of you shews that each one of us should call together in his city the chiefs of the Donatists either alone and with one of his neighbour bishops, so that in like manner in the different cities and places there should be meetings of them assembled by the magistrates or seniors of the places.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1646
verses.text: And let this be made an edict if it seems good to all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1647
verses.text: And all the bishops said: It seems good to all, and we all have confirmed this with our subscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1648
verses.text: Also we desire that your holiness sign the letters to be sent from the council to the judges.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1649
verses.text: Aurelius, the bishop, said: If it seems good to your charity, let the form of summoning them be read, in order that we all may hold the same tenour of proceeding.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1650
verses.text: All the bishops said: Let it be read.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1651
verses.text: Laetus the Notary read.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1652
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1653
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1654
verses.text: Let each of the bishops meet with the leaders of the Donatists in his own city; or let him associate with himself a neighbouring bishop, that they together may meet them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1655
verses.text: This introduction together with the propositions of the different bishops belongs to the Synod of Carthage of August, 403.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1656
verses.text: This canon (xcj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1657
verses.text: ) is Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1658
verses.text: of that synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1659
verses.text: Canon XCII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1660
verses.text: (Greek xcv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1661
verses.text: )  Form of convening the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1662
verses.text: That bishop of that church said: What by the authority of that most ample see we shall have impetrated, we ask your gravity to have read, and that you order it to be joined to the acts and carried into effect.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1663
verses.text: When the jussio had been read and joined to the acts, the bishop of the Catholic Church, said: Vouchsafe to listen to the mandate to be sent through your gravity to the Donatists, and to insert it in the acts, and to carry it to them, and informs us in your acts of their answer.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1664
verses.text: "We, sent by the authority of our Catholic Council, have called you together, desiring to rejoice in your correction, bearing in mind the charity of the Lord who said: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God; and moreover he admonished through the prophet those who say they are not our brothers, that we ought to say: Ye are our brethren.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1665
verses.text: Therefore you ought not to despise this pacific commonitory coming of love, so that if ye think we have any part of the truth, ye do not hesitate to say so: that is, when your council is gathered together, ye delegate of your number certain to whom you intrust the statement of your case; so that we may be able to do this also, that there shall be delegated from our Council who with them delegated by you may discuss peacefully, at a determined place and time, whatever question there is which separates your communion from us; and that at length the old error may receive an end through the assistance of our Lord God, lest through the animosity of men, weak souls, and ignorant people should perish by sacrilegious dissension.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1666
verses.text: But if ye shall accept this proposition in a fraternal spirit, the truth will easily shine forth, but if ye are not willing to do this, your distrust will be easily known".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1667
verses.text: And when this had been read, all the bishops said: This pleases us well, so let it be.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1668
verses.text: And they subscribed: I, Aurelius, bishop of the Carthaginian Church, have consented to this decree, and having read it, have subscribed it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1669
verses.text: Likewise also the rest of the bishops signed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1670
verses.text: This synod sent a legation to the Princes against the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1671
verses.text: The most glorious emperor Honorius Augustus, being consul for the sixth time, on the Calends of July, at Carthage in the basilica of the second region.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1672
verses.text: In this council Theasius and Euodius received a legation against the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1673
verses.text: In this council was inserted the commonitorium which follows.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1674
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1675
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1676
verses.text: What things should be said to the Donatists are these: "We greatly desire to rejoice in your conversion; for we have been commanded to say even to those not desiring to be our brethren, 'Ye are our brothers.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1677
verses.text: ' We come therefore to you and we exhort you that if you have any defence to make, ye should appoint certain persons to whom this should be entrusted, who, at a fixed time and place, shall urge your case; otherwise your distrust wilt be thenceforward patent".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1678
verses.text: This canon is Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1679
verses.text: of the Synod of Carthage of August 25, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1680
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1682
verses.text: Canon XCIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1683
verses.text: (Greek xcvi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1684
verses.text: )  The character of the Commonitory which the legates received against the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1685
verses.text: The Commonitorium for our brothers Theasius and Evodius, sent as legates from the Council of Carthage to the most glorious and most religious princes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1686
verses.text: When by the help of the Lord they are come into the presence of the most pious princes, they shall declare to them with what fulness of confidence, according to the direction of the council of the year before, the prelates of the Donatists had been urged by the municipal authority to assemble, in order that if they really meant their professions, they might by fit persons chosen from their number, enter into a peaceful conference with us in Christian meekness, and whatever they held as truth they might not hesitate to declare it frankly; so that from such conference the sincerity of the Catholic position, which has been conspicuous for so long a time, might be perceived even by those who from ignorance or obstinacy were opposing themselves to it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1687
verses.text: But deterred by their want of confidence they scarcely ventured to reply.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1688
verses.text: And forsooth, because we had discharged toward them the offices which become bishops and peacemakers, and they had no answer to make to the truth, they betook themselves to unreasonable acts of brute force, and treacherously oppressed many of the bishops and clergy, to say nothing of the laity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1689
verses.text: And some of the churches they actually invaded, and tried to assault still others.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1690
verses.text: And now, it behoves the gracious clemency of their Majesties to take measures that the Catholic Church, which has begotten them as worshippers of Christ in her womb, and has nourished them with the strong meat of the faith, should by their forethought, be defended, lest violent men, taking advantage of the times of religious excitement, should by fear overcome a weak people, whom by argument they were not able to pervert.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1691
verses.text: It is well known how often the vile gatherings (detestabilis manus) of the Circumcelliones have been forbidden by the laws, and also condemned by many decrees of the Emperors, their majesties most religious predecessors.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1692
verses.text: Against the madness of these people it is not unusual nor contrary to the holy Scriptures to ask for secular [θείας in the Greek] protection, since Paul the Apostle, as is related in the authentic Acts of the Apostles, warded off a conspiracy of certain lawless men by the help of the military.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1693
verses.text: Now then we ask that there be extended to the Catholic Churches, without any dissimulation, the protection of the ordinum [i-e: companies of soldiers, stationed] in each city, and of the holders of the suburban estates in the various places.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1694
verses.text: At the same time it will be necessary to ask that they give commandment that the law, set forth by their father Theodosius, of pious memory, which imposed a fine of ten pounds of gold upon both the ordainers and the ordained among heretics, and which was also directed against proprietors at whose houses conventicles were held, be confirmed anew; so that it may be effective with persons of this sort when Catholics, provoked by their wiles, shall lay complaint against them; so that through fear at least, they may cease from making schisms and from the wickedness of the heretics, since they refuse to be cleansed and corrected by the thought of the eternal punishment.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1695
verses.text: Let request be also made that the law depriving heretics of the power of being able to receive or bequeath by gift or by will, be straightway renewed by their Piety, so that all right of giving or receiving may be taken away from those who, blinded by the madness of obstinacy, are determined to continue in the error of the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1696
verses.text: With regard to those who by considerations of unity and peace are willing to correct themselves, let permission be granted to them to receive their inheritance, the law notwithstanding, even though the bequest by gift or inheritance was made while they were yet living in the error of the heretics; those of course being excepted, who under the stress of legal proceedings have sought to enter the Catholic Church; for it may well be supposed, that persons of this latter sort desired Catholic unity, not so much from fear of the judgment of heaven, as from the greed of earthly gain.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1697
verses.text: For the furtherance of all these things the help of the Powers (Potestatum) of each one of the provinces is needed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1698
verses.text: With regard to other matters, whatever they shall perceive is for the Church's interests, this we have resolved that the legation have full authority to do and to carry into effect.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1699
verses.text: Moreover it seemed good to us all, that letters from our assembly should be sent to the most glorious Emperors and most Excellent Worthinesses, whereby they may be assured of the agreement of us all that the legates should be sent by us to their most blessed court.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1700
verses.text: Since it is a very slow business for us all to set our names to these letters, and in order that they may not be burdened with the signature of each one of us, we desire thee, brother Aurelius, that thy charity be good enough to sign them in the name of us all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1701
verses.text: And to this they all agreed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1702
verses.text: I, Aurelius, Bishop of the Church of Carthage have consented to this decree and have subscribed my name.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1703
verses.text: And so all the other bishops subscribed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1704
verses.text: Letters ought likewise to be sent to the judges that, until the lord permit the legates to return to us, they give protection through the soldiers of the cities, and through the holders of the farms of the Catholic Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1705
verses.text: It ought also to be added concerning the dishonest Equitius, which he had shewn by laying claim to the jus sacerdotum, that he be rejected from the diocese of Hippo according to the statutes of the Emperors.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1706
verses.text: Letters ought also to be sent to the Bishop of the Church of Rome in commendation of the legates, and to the other Bishops who may be where the Emperor is.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1707
verses.text: To this they assented.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1708
verses.text: Likewise I, Aurelius, Bishop of the Church of Carthage, have consented to this decree, and having read it, have set my name to it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1709
verses.text: And all the other bishops likewise subscribed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1710
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1711
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1712
verses.text: The Emperors who were born in the true religion and were educated in the faith, ought to stretch forth a helping hand to the Churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1713
verses.text: For the military band overthrew the dire conspiracy which was threatening Paul.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1714
verses.text: Here follows a brief declaration of what things were decreed in this Synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1715
verses.text: When Stilico a second time and Anthemius, those illustrious men, were consuls, on the tenth before the calends of September, at Carthage in the basilica of the second region.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1716
verses.text: I have not written out in full the acts of this council because they treat of the necessities of the time rather than of matters of general interest, but for the instruction of the studious I have added a brief digest of the same council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1717
verses.text: Canon XCIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1718
verses.text: (Greek xcvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1719
verses.text: )  Summary of Chapters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1720
verses.text: That a free delegation be sent to the council from all the provinces to Mizoneum.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1721
verses.text: Legates and letters were ordered to be sent for the purpose of directing the free legation: that became the unity had been made only at Carthage, letters should also be given to the judges, that they might order in the other provinces and cities the work of union to be proceeded with, and the thanksgivings of the Church of Carthage for the whole of Africa concerning the exclusion of the Donatists should be sent with the letters of the bishops to Court (ad Comitatum).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1722
verses.text: The letters of Pope Innocent were read: that bishops ought not readily to carry causes across seas, and this very thing was confirmed by the judgment of the bishops themselves; that on account of thanksgiving and the exclusion of the Donatists, two clerics of the Church of Carthage should be sent to Court.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1723
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1724
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1725
verses.text: It seemed good that letters be sent to the Magistrates that the Donatists be expelled.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1726
verses.text: This introduction is taken from the Synod of Carthage of August 23, 405.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1727
verses.text: There is also added the introduction of the Synod of Carthage of June 13, 407.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1728
verses.text: In this synod certain things already decreed are corrected.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1729
verses.text: Under the most illustrious emperors Honorius for the VIIth time, and Theodosius for the second time, the consuls being the Augusti, on the Ides of July in Carthage in the basilica of the second region, when bishop Aurelius together with his other bishops had taken his seat, and while the deacons stood by, he said: Since it was decreed in the council of Hippo, that each year there should assemble a plenary council of Africa, not only here in Carthage but also in the different provinces in their order, and this was reserved that we should determine its place of meeting sometimes in Numidia and sometimes in Byzacium.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1730
verses.text: But this seemed laborious to all the brethren.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1731
verses.text: Canon XCV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1732
verses.text: (Greek xcviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1733
verses.text: )  An universal council to be held only when necessary.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1734
verses.text: It seemed good that there should be no more the yearly necessity of fatiguing the brethren; but as often as common cause, that is of the whole of Africa, demands, that letters shall be given on every side to that see in this matter, that a synod should be gathered in that province, where the desirability of it induces; but let the causes which are not of general interest be judged in their own provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1735
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1736
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon XCV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1737
verses.text: When general necessity so urges, letters are to be sent to the chief see, and a synod held in a convenient place.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1738
verses.text: But let ordinary causes be settled in their own provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1739
verses.text: This canon is Canon j.
