verses.text: )  That from judges who have been chosen, no appeals may be taken.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1748
verses.text: If an appeal be taken, let him who makes it choose the judges, and with him he also against whom the appeal is taken; and from their decision no appeal may be made.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1749
verses.text: Concerning the delegates of the different provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1750
verses.text: When all the delegates of the different provinces came together, they have been most graciously received, that is those of the Numidians, Byzacenes, Stifensian Moors, as well as Caesarians and Tripolitans.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1751
verses.text: Concerning the executors of Churches.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1752
verses.text: It has seemed good moreover that the appointment of five executors should be asked for in all matters pertaining to the necessities of the Church, who shall be portioned off in the different provinces.

verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1755
verses.text: If one party to a suit takes an appeal, and if both choose together a judge, no further appeal shall be allowed.

verses.text: It seemed good that the legates who were about leaving, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1764
verses.text: , Vincent and Fortunatian, should in the name of all the provinces ask from the most glorious Emperors to give a faculty for the establishment of scholastic defensors, whose shall be the care of this very kind of business: so that as the priests of the province, they who have received the faculty as defensors of the Churches in ecclesiastical affairs, as often as necessity arises, may be able to enter the private apartments of the judges, so as to resist what is urged on the other side, or to make necessary explanations.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1769

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1770
verses.text: It seemed good that the chosen legates should have at the meeting freedom of action (legationem liberam).

verses.text: The protest of the Mauritanian bishops against Primosus.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1772
verses.text: It is evident that those of Mauritania Caesariensis gave evidence in their own writings that Primosus had been summoned by the chiefs of the Thiganensian city, that he should present himself to the plenary council according to the imperial constitutions, and, when sought for, as was right, Primosus was not found, at least so the deacons reported.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1773
verses.text: But since the same Mauritanians petitioned that letters be sent from the whole synod to the venerable brother, the aged Innocent, it seemed good that they should be sent, that he might know that Primosus had been sought at the council and not found at all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1793
verses.text: It seemed good that such peoples as had never had bishops of their own should in no way receive such unless it had been decreed in a plenary council of each province and by the primates, and with the consent of the bishop of that diocese to which the church belonged.

verses.text: Whoso never heretofore had a bishop of their own, unless the general synod of the Province shall agree to it, and the Primate, in agreement with him to whom the province in which the Church is, is subject, shall not have bishops of their own.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1803
verses.text: )  Of people or dioceses returned from the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1804
verses.text: Such communities as have returned from the Donatists and have had bishops, without doubt may continue to have them even without any action of the councils, but such a community as had a bishop and when he dies wish no longer to have a bishop of their own, but to belong to the diocese of some other bishop, this is not to be denied them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1805
verses.text: Also such bishops as before the promulgation of the imperial law concerning unity as brought back their people to the Catholic Church, they ought to be allowed still to rule them: but from the time of that law of unity, all the Churches, and their dioceses, and if perchance there be any instruments of the Church or things pertaining to its rights should belong to the Catholic bishops of those places to whom the places pertained while under the heretics, whether they be converted to the Catholic Church or remain unconverted heretics.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1806
verses.text: Whoever after this law shall make any such usurpation, shall restore as is meet the usurped possessions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1807
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1808

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1809
verses.text: Whoever are converted from the Donatists may retain their own bishops, although they had them without the consent of the synod; and when the bishop is dead, if they do not wish another to be substituted in his room, but desire to place themselves under some other bishop, they shall be allowed to do so.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1810
verses.text: And such bishops as before the union have brought back the people they ruled, let them still rule them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1811
verses.text: After the imperial Edict on Unity every church must defend its own rights.

verses.text: bis)  Of making peace between the Churches of Rome and Alexandria.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1847
verses.text: It seemed good that a letter be written to the holy Pope Innocent concerning the dissension between the Churches of Rome and Alexandria, so that each Church might keep peace with the other as the Lord commanded.

verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1850

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1857
verses.text: )  Of those who put away their wives or husbands, that so they remain.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1858
verses.text: It seemed good that according to evangelical and apostolical discipline a man who had been put away from his wife, and a woman put away from her husband should not be married to another, but so should remain, or else be reconciled the one to the other; but if they spurn this law, they shall be forced to do penance, covering which case we must petition that an imperial law be promulgated.

verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1875

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1890
verses.text: It seemed good that whoever should seek from the Emperor, that secular judges should take cognizance of his business, should be deprived of his office; if however, he had asked from the Emperor an episcopal trial, no objection should be made.

verses.text: (Greek cix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1914
verses.text: )  That those who are going to carry their case to court should be careful to inform either the bishop of Carthage or the bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1915
verses.text: It seemed good that whoever wished to go to court, should give notice in the form which is sent to the Church of the city of Rome, that from thence also he should receive a formed letter to court.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1916
verses.text: But if receiving only a formed letter to Rome, and saying nothing about the necessity which he had of going to court, he willed immediately to go thither, let him be cut off from communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1917
verses.text: But if while at Rome the necessity of going to court suddenly arose, let him state his necessity to the bishop of Rome and let him carry with him a rescript of the same Roman bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1918
verses.text: But let the formed letters which are issued by primates and by certain bishops to their own clergy have the date of Easter; but if it be yet uncertain what is the date of Easter of that year, let the preceding Easter's date be set down, as it is customary to date public acts after the consulship.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1919
verses.text: It further seemed good that those who were sent as delegates from this glorious council should ask of the most glorious princes whatever they saw would be useful against the Donatists and Pagans, and their superstitions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1920
verses.text: It also seemed good to all the bishops that all conciliar letters be signed by your holiness alone.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1921
verses.text: And they subscribed: I, Aurelius, Bishop of Carthage, have consented to this decree, and having read it, now subscribe my name.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1922

verses.name: Council of Carthage 1:1925
verses.text: Whatever shall seem to the legates useful against the Donatists and Greeks, and their superstitions, that shall be sought from the Emperor.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:46
verses.text: When Aurelius the bishop presided over the whole council, the deacons standing by, it pleased all the bishops, whose names and subscriptions are indicated, met together in the holy synod of the Church of Carthage to define—            Canon CIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:50
verses.text: That whosoever says that Adam, the first man, was created mortal, so that whether he had sinned or not, he would have died in body—that is, he would have gone forth of the body, not because his sin merited this, but by natural necessity, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:53

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:61
verses.text: (Greek cxii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:62
verses.text: bis)  That infants are baptized for the remission of sins.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:63
verses.text: Likewise it seemed good that whosoever denies that infants newly from their mother's wombs should be baptized, or says that baptism is for remission of sins, but that they derive from Adam no original sin, which needs to be removed by the laver of regeneration, from whence the conclusion follows, that in them the form of baptism for the remission of sins, is to be understood as false and not true, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:64
verses.text: For no otherwise can be understood what the Apostle says, "By one man sin is come into the world, and death through sin, and so death passed upon all men in that all have sinned," than the Catholic Church everywhere diffused has always understood it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:65
verses.text: For on account of this rule of faith (regulam fidei) even infants, who could have committed as yet no sin themselves, therefore are truly baptized for the remission of sins, in order that what in them is the result of generation may be cleansed by regeneration.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:66
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:67
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:68
verses.text: Whoso affirms that those newly born and baptized contract nothing from Adam's transgression, which needs to be washed away by baptism, is to be execrated: for through one both death and sin invaded the whole world.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:69
verses.text: This is Canon ij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:76
verses.text: [Also it seemed good, that if anyone should say that the saying of the Lord, "In my Father's house are many mansions" is to be understood as meaning that in the kingdom of heaven there will be a certain middle place, or some place somewhere, in which infants live in happiness who have gone forth from this life without baptism, without which they cannot enter the kingdom of heaven, which is eternal life, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:77
verses.text: For after our Lord has said: "Except a man be born again of water and of the Holy Spirit he shall not enter the kingdom of heaven," what Catholic can doubt that he who has not merited to be coheir with Christ shall become a sharer with the devil: for he who fails of the right hand without doubt shall receive the left hand portion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:78
verses.text: ]  Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:79
verses.text: The foregoing, says Surius, is found in this place in a very ancient codex.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:80

verses.text: Canon CXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:83
verses.text: (Greek cxiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:84
verses.text: )  That the grace of God not only gives remission of sins, but also affords aid that we sin no more.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:85
verses.text: Likewise it seemed good, that whoever should say that the grace of God, by which a man is justified through Jesus Christ our Lord, avails only for the remission of past sins, and not for assistance against committing sins in the future, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:86
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:87
verses.text: Whoever is of opinion that the grace of God only gives remission of those sins we have already committed, and does not afford aid against sin in the future, is to be twice execrated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:88
verses.text: Canon CXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:89
verses.text: (Greek cxiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:90
verses.text: continued.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:91
verses.text: )  That the grace of Christ gives not only the knowledge of our duty, but also inspires us with a desire that we may be able to accomplish what we know.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:92
verses.text: Also, whoever shall say that the same grace of God through Jesus Christ our Lord helps us only in not sinning by revealing to us and opening to our understanding the commandments, so that we may know what to seek, what we ought to avoid, and also that we should love to do so, but that through it we are not helped so that we are able to do what we know we should do, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:93
verses.text: For when the Apostle says: "Wisdom puffeth up, but charity edifieth" it were truly infamous were we to believe that we have the grace of Christ for that which puffeth us up, but have it not for that which edifieth, since in each case it is the gift of God, both to know what we ought to do, and to love to do it; so that wisdom cannot puff us up while charity is edifying us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:94
verses.text: For as of God it is written, "Who teacheth man knowledge," so also it is written, "Love is of God".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:95
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:96
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:97
verses.text: Whoever says that the grace of God is given to us only that we may know what we ought to do and what to flee from, but not also that we may love the thing known, and be able to accomplish it, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:98
verses.text: Canon cxi.

verses.text: is Canon iij.

verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:105
verses.text: Canon CXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:106
verses.text: (Greek cxiiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:107
verses.text: )  That without the grace of God we can do no good thing.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:108
verses.text: It seemed good that whosoever should say that the grace of justification was given to us only that we might be able more readily by grace to perform what we were ordered to do through our free will; as if though grace was not given, although not easily, yet nevertheless we could even without grace fulfil the divine commandments, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:109
verses.text: For the Lord spake concerning the fruits of the commandments, when he said: "Without me ye can do nothing," and not "Without me ye could do it but with difficulty".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:110
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:111
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:112
verses.text: Whoso preaches that without grace we could keep the commandments although with difficulty, is to be thrice execrated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:113
verses.text: For the Lord says, "Without me ye can do nothing".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:114
verses.text: This is Canon V.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:115
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:116
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:118
verses.text: Canon CXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:119
verses.text: (Greek cxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:120
verses.text: )  That not only humble but also true is that voice of the Saints: "If we say that we have no sin we deceive ourselves".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:121
verses.text: It also seemed good that as St.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:122
verses.text: John the Apostle says, "If we shall say that we have no sin we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us," whosoever thinks that this should be so understood as to mean that out of humility, we ought to say that we have sin, and not because it is really so, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:123
verses.text: For the Apostle goes on to add, "But if we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all iniquity," where it is sufficiently clear that this is said not only of humility but also truly.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:124
verses.text: For the Apostle might have said, "If we shall say we have no sins we shall extoll ourselves, and humility shall have no place in us;" but when he says, "we deceive ourselves and the truth is not in us" he sufficiently intimates that he who affirmed that he had no sin would speak not that which is true but that which is false.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:125
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:126
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:127
verses.text: Whosoever shall interpret the saying of the Divine [i-e: St.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:128
verses.text: John]: "If we shall say that we have no sin, we deceive ourselves" as not being really true but as spoken out of humility, let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:129
verses.text: This is Canon vj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:130
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:131
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:133
verses.text: Canon CXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:134
verses.text: (Greek cxvi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:135
verses.text: )  That in the Lord's Prayer the Saints say for themselves: "Forgive us our trespasses".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:136
verses.text: It has seemed good that whoever should say that when in the Lord's prayer, the saints say, "forgive us our trespasses," they say this not for themselves, because they have no need of this petition, but for the rest who are sinners of the people; and that therefore no one of the saints can say, "Forgive me my trespasses," but "Forgive us our trespasses;" so that the just is understood to seek this for others rather than for himself; let him be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:137
verses.text: For holy and just was the Apostle James, when he said, "For in many things we offend all".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:138
verses.text: For why was it added "all," unless that this sentence might agree also with the psalm, where we read, "Enter not into judgment with thy servant, O Lord, for in thy sight shall no man living be justified;" and in the prayer of the most wise Solomon: "There is no man that sinneth not;" and in the book of the holy Job: "He sealeth in the hand of every man, that every man may know his own infirmity;" wherefore even the holy and just Daniel when in prayer said several times: "We have sinned, we have done iniquity," and other things which there truly and humbly he confessed; nor let it be thought (as some have thought) that this was said not of his own but rather of the people's sins, for he said further on: "When I shall pray and confess my sins and the sins of my people to the Lord my God;" he did not wish to say our sins, but he said the sins of his people and his own sins, since he as a prophet foresaw that those who were to come would thus misunderstand his words.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:139
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:140
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:141
verses.text: Whoso expounds this, "forgive us our trespasses" as speaking only of the multitude and not of individuals let him be anathema: Since Daniel even he can behold saying with the multitude "I confessed my sins and the sins of my people".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:142
verses.text: This is Canon vij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:143
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:144
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:146
verses.text: Canon CXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:147
verses.text: (Greek cxvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:148
verses.text: )  That the Saints say with accuracy, "Forgive us our trespasses".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:149
verses.text: Likewise also it seemed good, that whoever wished that these words of the Lord's prayer, when we say, "Forgive us our trespasses" are said by the saints out of humility and not in truth let them be anathema.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:150
verses.text: For who would make a lying prayer, not to men but to God? Who would say with his lips that he wished his sins forgiven him, but in his heart that he had no sins to be forgiven.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:151
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:152
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:153
verses.text: (Lacking.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:154
verses.text: )  This is Canon viij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:155
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:156
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:158
verses.text: Canon CXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:159
verses.text: (Greek cxviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:160
verses.text: )  Of peoples converted from the Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:161
verses.text: Item, it seemed good, since it was so decreed some years ago by a plenary council, that whatever churches were erected in a diocese before the laws were made concerning Donatists when they became Catholic, should pertain to the sees of those bishops through whom their return to Catholic unity was brought about; but after the laws whatever churches communicated were to belong there where they belonged when they were Donatists.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:162
verses.text: But because many controversies afterward arose and are still springing up between bishops concerning dioceses, which were not then at all in prospect, now it has seemed good to this council, that wherever there was a Catholic and a Donatist party, pertaining to different sees, at whatever time unity has been or shall be made, whether before or after the laws, the churches shall belong to that see to which the Catholic church which was already there belonged.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:163
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:164
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:165
verses.text: Whenever conversions and unions of Donatists are effected, let them be subject to that throne to which the Catholic Church which was formerly there was subject.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:166
verses.text: This is Canon ix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:167
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:168
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:170
verses.text: Canon CXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:171
verses.text: (Greek cxix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:172
verses.text: )  How bishops as well Catholic as those who have been converted from the Donatists are to divide between themselves the dioceses.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:173
verses.text: So, too, it has seemed good that if a bishop has been converted from the Donatists to Catholic unity, that equally there should be divided what shall have been so found where there were two parties; that is, that some places should pertain to one and some to the other; and let the division be made by him who has been the longest time in the episcopate, and let the younger choose.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:174
verses.text: But should there be only one place let it belong to him who is found to be the nearer.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:175
verses.text: But should the distance be equal to each of the two cathedrals let it belong to the one the people may choose.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:176
verses.text: But should the old Catholics wish their own bishop, and if the same be the case with the converted Donatists, let the will of the greater number prevail, but should the parties be equal, let it belong to him who has been longest bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:177
verses.text: But if so many places be found in which there were both parties, that an equal division is impossible, as for example, if they are unequal in number, after those places have been distributed which have an equal number, the place that remains over shall be disposed of as is provided above in the case where there is but one place to be treated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:178
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:179
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:180
verses.text: Those who have been converted from Donatus, let them divide the dioceses; and let the senior bishop make the division, and the junior choose which he will.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:181
verses.text: This is Canon x.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:182
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:183
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:185
verses.text: Canon CXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:186
verses.text: (Greek cxx.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:187
verses.text: )  That if a bishop shall possess a diocese which he has snatched from heresy for three years, no one may take it from him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:188
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that if anyone after the laws should convert any place to Catholic unity and retain it for three years without opposition, it should not be taken away from him afterwards.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:189
verses.text: If however there was during those three years a bishop who could claim it and was silent, he shall lose the opportunity.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:190
verses.text: But if there was no bishop, no prejudice shall happen to the see, but it shall be lawful when the place that had none shall receive a bishop, to make the claim within three years of that day.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:191
verses.text: Item, if a Donatist bishop shall be converted to the Catholic party, the time that has elapsed shall not count against him, but from the day of his conversion for three years he shall have the right of making a claim on the places which belonged to his See.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:192
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:193
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:194
verses.text: Whosoever shall convert a region to Orthodoxy and shall keep it converted for three years, let him be without blame.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:195
verses.text: But if the bishop converted from Donatus within three years of its conversion seeks his diocese again, let it be returned to him (εἰ ἐνάγει, ἐναγέτω.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:196
verses.text: )  This is Canon xj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:197
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:198
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:200
verses.text: Canon CXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:201
verses.text: (Greek cxxi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:202
verses.text: )  Of those who intrude upon peoples which they think belong to them, without the consent of those by whom they are held.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:203
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that whatever bishops seek the peoples whom they consider to pertain to their see, not by bringing their causes before the episcopal judges, but rush in while another is holding the place, all such, (whether said people are willing to receive them or no) shall lose their case.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:204
verses.text: And whoever have done this, if the contention between the two bishops is not yet finished but still going on, let him depart who intruded without the decree of the ecclesiastical judges; nor let anyone flatter himself that he will retain [what he has seized] if he shall obtain letters from the primate, but whether he has such letters or has them not, it is suitable that he who holds and receives his letters should make it appear then that he has held the church pertaining to him peaceably.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:205
verses.text: But if he has referred any question, let the cause be decided by the episcopal judges, whether those whom the primates have appointed for them, or the neighbouring bishops whom they have chosen by common consent.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:206
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:207
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:208
verses.text: Let no one seize for himself what he thinks belongs to him: but let the bishops judge or whom the Primate will give, or whom the neighbouring bishops shall give with his consent.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:209
verses.text: But whosoever has received letters from the primate concerning the keeping [of such regions and churches] merely deceives himself.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:210
verses.text: This is Canon xij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:211
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:212
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:214
verses.text: Canon CXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:215
verses.text: (Greek cxxii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:216
verses.text: )  Of those who neglect the peoples belonging to them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:217
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that whoever neglect to bring the places belonging to their see into Catholic unity should be admonished by the neighbouring diligent bishops, that they delay no longer to do this; but if within six months from the day of the convention they do nothing, let them pertain to him who can win them: but with this proviso however, that if he to whom it seemed they naturally belonged can prove that this neglect was intentional and more efficacious in winning them than the greater apparent diligence of others; when the episcopal judges shall be convinced that this is the case, they shall restore the places to his see.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:218
verses.text: If the bishops between whom the cause lies are of different provinces, let the Primate in whose province the place is situated about which there is the dispute, appoint judges; but if by mutual consent they have chosen as judges the neighbouring bishops, let one or three be chosen: so that if they choose three they may follow the sentence of all or of two.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:219
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:220
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:221
verses.text: If any neglect what belongs to their jurisdiction, let them be admonished; and if they shall do nothing within a six month, let them be adjudged to him who can win them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:222
verses.text: But if they have committed the neglect out of policy so as not to irritate the heretics, and this shall appear to have been the case, their sees shall be restored to them, by the judgment of the bishops either appointed or elected.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:223
verses.text: This is Canon xiij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:224
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:225
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:227
verses.text: Canon CXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:228
verses.text: (Greek cxxiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:229
verses.text: )  The sentence of the elected judges ought not to be spurned.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:230
verses.text: From the judges chosen by common consent of the parties, no appeal can be taken; and whoever shall be found to have carried such an appeal and contumaciously to be unwilling to submit to the judges, when this has been proved to the primate, let him give letters, that no one of the bishops should communicate with him until he yield.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:231
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:232
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:233
verses.text: A judge chosen by both parties cannot be repudiated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:234
verses.text: This is Canon xiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:235
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:236
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:238
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:239
verses.text: See Canons 76 (79) and 80 (83).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:240
verses.text: Canon CXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:241
verses.text: (Greek cxxiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:242
verses.text: )  That if a bishop neglects his diocese he is to be deprived of communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:243
verses.text: If in the mother cathedrals a bishop should have been negligent against the heretics, let a meeting be held of the neighbouring diligent bishops, and let his negligence be pointed out to him, so that he can have no excuse.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:244
verses.text: But if within six months after this meeting, if an execution was in his own province, and he had taken no care to convert them to Catholic unity, no one shall communicate with him till he does his duty.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:245
verses.text: But if no executor shall have come to the places, then the fault shall not be laid to the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:246
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:247
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:248
verses.text: A bishop who spurns the care of heretics, and if after being warned he continues for six months in his contempt, and has no care for their conversion, is to be excommunicated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:249
verses.text: This is Canon xv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:250
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:251
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:253
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:254
verses.text: So [i-e: "Metropoles"] I turn matrices cathedrae.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:255
verses.text: I know indeed there were no fixed ecclesiastical metropoles, in Africa; but they had civil metropoles called by that name, can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:256
verses.text: 86, (89) which see.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:257
verses.text: Of these officers [i-e: "Executors "] see can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:259
verses.text: Canon CXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:260
verses.text: (Greek cxxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:261
verses.text: )  Of bishops who shall lie with regard to Donatists' communions.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:262
verses.text: If it shall be proven that any bishop has lied concerning the communion of those [who had been Donatists], and had said that they had communicated when he knew it was an established fact that they had not done so, let him lose his bishoprick.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:263
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:264
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:265
verses.text: Whoso says that a man, whom he knows does not communicate, does communicate is to be deprived of his episcopate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:266
verses.text: This is Canon xvj.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:267
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:268
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:270
verses.text: Canon CXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:271
verses.text: (Greek cxxvi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:272
verses.text: )  That presbyters and clerics are not to appeal except to African Synods.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:273
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that presbyters, deacons, or other of the lower clergy who are to be tried, if they question the decision of their bishops, the neighbouring bishops having been invited by them with the consent of their bishops, shall hear them and determine whatever separates them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:274
verses.text: But should they think an appeal should be carried from them, let them not carry the appeal except to African councils or to the primates of their provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:275
verses.text: But whoso shall think of carrying an appeal across seas he shall be admitted to communion by no one in Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:276
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:277
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:278
verses.text: A presbyter and deacons, who has been condemned by his own bishop, let him appeal to the neighbouring bishops: but let them not cross the sea.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:279
verses.text: In Africa they shall be excommunicated.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:280
verses.text: This is Canon xvij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:281
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:282
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:284
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:285
verses.text: A repetition of Canon 28 (31).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:286
verses.text: Canon CXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:287
verses.text: (Greek cxxvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:288
verses.text: )  That Virgins, even when minors, should be given the veil.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:289
verses.text: Item, it seemed good that whatever bishop, by the necessity of the dangers of virginal purity, when either a powerful suitor or some ravisher is feared, or if she shall be pricked with some scruple of death that she might die unveiled, at the demand either of her parents or of those to whose care she has been entrusted, shall give the veil to a virgin, or shall have given it while she was under twenty-five years of age, the council which has appointed that number of years shall not oppose him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:290
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:291
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:292
verses.text: Whosoever has veiled or shall veil a virgin before she is twenty-five years of age (that is give her the habit, or clothe her), being forced thereto on account of a powerful lover, or a ravisher, or deadly disease, provided those who have the charge of her so exhort, shall receive no damage from the synod concerning that age.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:293
verses.text: This is Canon xviij.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:294
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:295
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:297
verses.text: The reference to a former canon is to Canon j.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:298
verses.text: of the second series of the canons of the Synod of Hippo in a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:299
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:301
verses.text: Canon CXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:302
verses.text: (Greek cxxviii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:303
verses.text: )  That bishops be not detained too long in council, let them choose three judges from themselves of the singular provinces.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:304
verses.text: Item, it seemed good, lest all the bishops who are assembled at a council be kept too long, that the whole synod should choose three judges of the several provinces; and they elected for the province of Carthage Vincent, Fortunatian, and Clarus; for the province of Numidia Alypius, Augustine, and Restitutus; for the province of Byzacena, with the holy Senex Donatian the Primate, Cresconius, Jocundus, and aemilian; for Mauritania Sitephensis Severian, Asiaticus, and Donatus; for the Tripolitan province Plautius, who alone was sent as legate according to custom; all these were to take cognizance of all things with the holy senex Aurelius, from whom the whole council sought that he should subscribe all things done by the council whether acts or letters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:305
verses.text: And they subscribed: I, Aurelius, bishop of the church of Carthage consent to this decree and having read it sign my name.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:306
verses.text: Likewise also signed they all.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:307
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:308
verses.text: Whenever the bishops who come to synod can remain no longer in attendance, let three be chosen from each province.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:309
verses.text: This is Canon xix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:310
verses.text: of Carthage, a.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:311
verses.text: d.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:313
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:314
verses.text: Two Sancti Senes mentioned, who we are sure were both primates.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:315
verses.text: See can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:317
verses.text: See can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:319
verses.text: And here we have an ancient precedent for synods delegating their authority to a committee, with the primate of all Africa at the head of it.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:320
verses.text: Item, at this council there was present a legation from the Roman Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:321
verses.text: After the consulate of the most glorious emperors Honorius for the XIIth.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:322
verses.text: time and Theodosius for the VIIIth.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:323
verses.text: , Augusti, on the III.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:324
verses.text: Calends of June, at Carthage, in the Secretarium of the restored basilica, when Aurelius the bishop together with Faustinus of the church of Potentia in the Italian province of Picenum, a legate of the Roman Church, Vincent of Calvita (Culositanus), Fortunatian of Naples, Marianus Uzipparensis, Adeodatus of Simidica, Pentadius of Carpi, Rufinian of Muzuba, Praetextatus of Sicily, Quodvultdeus of Veri (Verensis), Candidus of Abbirita, Gallonian of Utica, legates of the proconsular province; Alypius of Tagaste, Augustine of Hippo Regia and Posidonius of Calama, legates of the province of Numidia; Maximian of Aquae, Jocundus of Sufetula, and Hilary of Horrea-Cascilia, legates of the province of Byzacena; Novatus of Sitifi and Leo of Mocta, legates of the province of Mauritania Sitiphensis; Ninellus of Rusucarrum, Laurence of Icosium and Numerian of Rusgunium, legates of the Province of Mauritania Caesariensis, the judges chosen by the plenary council, had taken their seats, the deacons standing by, and when, after certain things had been accomplished, many bishops complained that it was not possible for them to wait for the completion of the rest of the business to be treated of, and that they must hasten to their own churches; it seemed good to the whole council, that by all some should be chosen from each province who should remain to finish up what was left to be done.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:325
verses.text: And it came about that those were present whose subscriptions testify that they were present.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:326
verses.text: Canon CXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:327
verses.text: (Greek cxxix.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:328
verses.text: )  That those out of communion should not be allowed to bring accusation.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:329
verses.text: It seemed good to all, as it had been decreed by the former councils, concerning what persons were to be admitted to bring accusations against clerics; and since it had not been expressed what persons should not be admitted, therefore we define, that he cannot properly be admitted to bring an accusation, who had been already excommunicated, and was still lying under that censure, whether he that wished to be the accuser were cleric or layman.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:330
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:331
verses.text: Ancient Epitome OF Canon CXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:332
verses.text: One excommunicated is not to give witness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:333
verses.text: The Council of Carthage of 419 had at its first session on May 25th done thus much.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:334
verses.text: But when it met again on the 30th of the same month, it continued the code.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:335
verses.text: The introduction in regard to this new session is this introduction.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:336
verses.text: The Canons then enacted were original, viz.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:338
verses.text: Canon CXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:339
verses.text: (Greek cxxx.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:340
verses.text: )  That slaves and freedmen and all infamous persons ought not to bring accusation.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:341
verses.text: To all it seemed good that no slaves or freedmen, properly so called, be admitted to accusation nor any of those who by the public laws are debarred from bringing accusation in criminal proceedings.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:342
verses.text: This also is the case with all those who have the stain of infamy, that is actors, and persons subject to turpitudes, also heretics, or heathen, or Jews; but even all those to whom the right of bringing accusation is denied, are not forbidden to bring accusation in their own suits.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:343
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:344
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXIX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:345
verses.text: A slave, and a freedman, and he who before was accused of any of these crimes on account of which he is not admitted in court, and a player, and a heathen, and a heretic, and a Jew.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:346
verses.text: [There is no verb to finish the sentence.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:347
verses.text: However, this is intended as a continuation of the epitome of the former canon, the words to be supplied being "are not to give witness".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:348
verses.text: ]  Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:349
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:350
verses.text: , Const.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:352
verses.text: Canon CXXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:353
verses.text: (Greek cxxxi.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:354
verses.text: )  That he who has failed to prove one charge shall not be allowed to give evidence to another.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:355
verses.text: So, too, it seemed good that as often as many crimes were laid to clerics by their accusers, and one of the first examined could not be proved, they should not be allowed to go on giving evidence on the other counts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:356
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXX.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:357
verses.text: He who makes many accusations and proves nothing [is not to give witness].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:358
verses.text: Canon CXXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:359
verses.text: (Greek CXXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:360
verses.text: )  Who should be allowed to give evidence.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:361
verses.text: They who are forbidden to be admitted as accusers are not to be allowed to appear as witnesses, nor any that the accuser may bring from his own household.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:362
verses.text: And none shall be admitted to give witness under fourteen years of age.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:363
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:364
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:365
verses.text: And whoso is not past fourteen years of age [is not to give witness].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:366
verses.text: An accuser is not to produce witnesses from his own house.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:367
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:368
verses.text: See Can.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:370
verses.text: Canon CXXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:371
verses.text: (Greek cxxxiii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:372
verses.text: )  Concerning a bishop who removes a man from communion who says he has confessed to the bishop alone his crime.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:373
verses.text: It also seemed good that if on any occasion a bishop said that someone had confessed to him alone a personal crime, and that the man now denies it; let not the bishop think that any slight is laid upon him if he is not believed on his own word alone, although he says he is not willing to communicate with the man so denying through a scruple of his own conscience.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:374
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:375
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:376
verses.text: If a bishop says "someone has confessed to me alone a crime," if the someone denies it, he [i-e: the bishop] is not easily to be believed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:377
verses.text: N.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:378
verses.text: B.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:379
verses.text: The word used for "someone" in the Epitome is πέλας, which ordinarily means a "neighbour" but may mean "any one".

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:380
verses.text: Vide Liddell and Scott.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:381
verses.text: Canon CXXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:382
verses.text: (Greek cxxxiv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:383
verses.text: )  That a bishop should not rashly deprive anyone of communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:384
verses.text: As long as his own bishop will not communicate with one excommunicated, the other bishops should have no communion with that bishop, that the bishop may be more careful not to charge anyone with what he cannot prove by documentary evidence to others.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:385
verses.text: (Greek cxxxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:386
verses.text: )  Bishop Aurelius said: According to the statutes of this whole assembled council, and the opinion of my littleness, it seems good to make an end of all the matters of the whole of the before-manifested title, and let the ecclesiastical acts receive the discussion of the present day's constitution.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:387
verses.text: And what things have not yet been expressed ("treated of" in the Greek) we shall write on the next day through our brethren, Bishop Faustinus and the Presbyters Philip and Asellus to our venerable brother and fellow-bishop Boniface; and they gave their assent in writing.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:388
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:389
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:390
verses.text: If a bishop deprives of communion an unconvicted man, he shall likewise be deprived of communion with his fellows.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:391
verses.text: Johnson.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:392
verses.text: Never was a more impartial law made, especially when all the legislators were bishops except two.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:393
verses.text: There were 217 bishops, and two priests, being legates from the bishop of Rome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:394
verses.text: The Greeks make a canon of the ratifications, and reckon no more than 135.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:395
verses.text: Aurelius, Bishop of Carthage, subscribes first, and after him 217 bishops, then Asellus and Philippus, priests, legates of the church of Rome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:396
verses.text: And it does not appear that any other priests were present in any of the councils, mentioned in the body of this code; but there is several times notice taken of the deacons who stood by.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:397
verses.text: Canon CXXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:398
verses.text: (Continuation of cxxxv.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:399
verses.text: in the Greek.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:400
verses.text: )  Here beginneth the letter directed from the whole African Council to Boniface, bishop of the City of Rome, by Faustinus the bishop, and Philip and Asellus the presbyters, legates of the Roman Church.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:401
verses.text: To the most blessed lord, and our honourable brother Boniface, Aurelius, Valentine of the primatial See of Numidia, and others present with us to the number of 217 from the whole council in Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:402
verses.text: Since it has pleased the Lord that our humility should write concerning those things which with us our holy brethren, Faustinus a fellow-bishop and Philip and Asellus, fellow presbyters, have done, not to the bishop Zosimus of blessed memory, from whom they brought commands and letters to us, but to your holiness, who art constituted in his room by divine authority, we ought briefly to set forth what has been determined upon by mutual consent; not indeed those things which are contained in the prolix volumes of the acts, in which, while charity was preserved, yet we loitered not without some little labour of altercation, deliberating those things in the acts which now pertain to the cause.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:403
verses.text: However the more gratefully would he have received this news as he would have seen a more peaceful ending of the matter, my lord and brother, had he been still in the body! Apiarius the presbyter, concerning whose ordination, excommunication, and appeal no small scandal arose not only at Sicca but also in the whole African Church, has been restored to communion upon his seeking pardon for all his sins.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:404
verses.text: First our fellow bishop Urban of Sicca doubtless corrected whatever in him seemed to need correction.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:405
verses.text: For there should have been kept in mind the peace and quiet of the Church not only in the present but also in the future, since so many evils of such a kind had gone before, that it was incumbent to take care that like or even graver evils should be prevented thereafter.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:406
verses.text: It seemed good to us that the presbyter Apiarius should be removed from the church of Sicca, retaining only the honour of his grade, and that he should exercise the office of the presbyterate wherever else he wished and could, having received a letter to this effect.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:407
verses.text: This we granted without difficulty at his own petition made in a letter.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:408
verses.text: But truly before this case should be thus closed, among other things which we were treating of in daily discussions, the nature of the case demanded that we should ask our brothers, Faustinus our fellow bishop, and Philip and Asellus our fellow presbyters, to set forth what they had been enjoined to treat of with us that they might be inserted in the ecclesiastical acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:409
verses.text: And they proceeded to make a verbal statement, but when we earnestly asked that they would present it rather in writing, then they produced the Commonitory.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:410
verses.text: This was read to us and also set down in the acts, which they are bringing with them to you.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:411
verses.text: In this they were bidden to treat of four things with us, first concerning the appeal of bishops to the Pontiff of the Roman Church, second that bishops should not unbecomingly be sailing to court, thirdly concerning the treating the causes of presbyters and deacons by contiguous bishops, if they had been wrongly excommunicated by their own, and fourthly concerning the bishop Urban who should be excommunicated or even sent to Rome, unless he should have corrected what seemed to need correction.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:412
verses.text: Of all which things concerning the first and third, that is that it is allowed to bishops to appeal to Rome and that the causes of clerics should be settled by the bishops of their own provinces, already last year we have taken pains to insinuate, in our letter to the same bishop Zosimus of venerable memory, that we were willing to observe these provisions for a little while without any injury to him, until the search for the statutes of the Council of Nice had been finished.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:413
verses.text: And now we ask of your holiness that you would cause to be observed by us the acts and constitutions of our fathers at the Council of Nice, and that you cause to be exercised by you there, those things which they brought in the commonitory: that is to say, If a bishop shall have been accused, etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:414
verses.text: [Here follows Canon vii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:415
verses.text: of Sardica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:416
verses.text: ]  Item concerning presbyters and deacons.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:417
verses.text: If any bishop has been quickly angered, etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:418
verses.text: [Here follows Canon xvii.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:419
verses.text: of Sardica.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:420
verses.text: ]  These are the things which have been inserted in the acts until the arrival of the most accurate copies of the Nicene Council, which things, if they are contained there (as in the Commonitory, which our brethren directed to us from the Apostolic See alleged) and be even kept according to that order by you in Italy, in no way could we be compelled either to endure such treatment as we are unwilling to mention or could suffer what is unbearable: but we believe, through the mercy of our Lord God, while your holiness presides over the Roman Church, we shall not have to suffer that pride (istum typhum passuri).

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:421
verses.text: And there will be kept toward us, what should be kept with brotherly love to us who are making no dispute.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:422
verses.text: You will also perceive according to the wisdom and the justice which the most Highest has given thee, what should be observed, if perchance the canons of the Council of Nice are other [than you suppose].

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:423
verses.text: For although we have read very many copies, yet never have we read in the Latin copies that there were any such decrees as are contained in the commonitory before mentioned.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:424
verses.text: So too, because we can find them in no Greek text here, we have desired that there should be brought to us from the Eastern Churches copies of the decrees, for it is said that there correct copies of the decrees are to be found.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:425
verses.text: For which end we beg your reverence, that you would deign yourself also to write to the pontiffs of these parts, that is of the churches of Antioch, Alexandria, and Constantinople, and to any others also if it shall please your holiness, that thence there may come to us the same canons decreed by the Fathers in the city of Nice, and thus you would confer by the help of the Lord this most great benefit upon all the churches of the West.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:426
verses.text: For who can doubt that the copies of the Nicene Council gathered in the Greek empire are most accurate, which although brought together from so diverse and from such noble Greek churches are found to agree when compared together? And until this be done, the provisions laid down to us in the Commonitory aforesaid, concerning the appeals of bishops to the pontiff of the Roman Church and concerning the causes of clerics which should be terminated by the bishops of their own provinces, we are willing to allow to be observed until the proof arrives and we trust your blessedness will help us in this according to the will of God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:427
verses.text: The rest of the matters treated and defined in our synod, since the aforesaid brethren, our fellow bishop Faustinus, and the presbyters Philip and Asellus are carrying the acts with them, if you deign to receive them, will make known to your holiness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:428
verses.text: And they signed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:429
verses.text: Our Lord keep thee to us for many years, most blessed brother.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:430
verses.text: Alypius, Augustine, Possidius, Marinus and the rest of the bishops (217) also signed.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:431
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXIV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:432
verses.text: Urban, the bishop of Siccas, is either to be excommunicated or else summoned to Rome unless he corrects what should be corrected by him.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:433
verses.text: Canon CXXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:434
verses.text: (Not numbered in the Greek.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:435
verses.text: )  Here begin the rescripts to the African Council from Cyril bishop of Alexandria in which he sends the authentic proceedings of the Nicene Council, translated from the Greek by Innocent the presbyter: these letters with the same Nicene council were also sent through the aforementioned presbyter Innocent and by Marcellus a subdeacon of the Church of Carthage, to the holy Boniface, bishop of the Roman Church, on the sixth day before the calends of December in the year 419.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:436
verses.text: To the most honourable lords, our holy brethren and fellow bishops, Aurelius, Valentinus, as well as to the whole holy synod met in Carthage, Cyril salutes your holiness in God.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:437
verses.text: I have received with all joy at the hands of our son, the presbyter Innocent, the letters of your reverence so full of piety, in which you express the hope that we will send you most accurate copies of the decrees of the holy Fathers at the Synod held at Nice the metropolis of Bithynia from the archives of our church; with our own certificate of accuracy attached thereto.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:438
verses.text: In answer to which request, most honourable lords and brethren, I have thought it necessary to send to you, with our compliments, by our son, Innocent the presbyter, the bearer of these, most faithful copies of the decisions of the synod held at Nice in Bithynia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:439
verses.text: And when ye have sought in the history of the church, you will find them there also.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:440
verses.text: Concerning Easter, as you have written, we announce to you that we shall celebrate it on the xviiith before the calends of May of the next indiction.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:441
verses.text: The subscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:442
verses.text: May God and our Lord preserve your holy synod as we desire, dear brethren.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:443
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXV.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:444
verses.text: According to your written request, we have sent to your charity most faithful copies of the authentic decrees of the Synod which was held at Nice, a city of Bithynia.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:445
verses.text: Canon CXXXVI.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:446
verses.text: (Not numbered in the Greek but with a new heading.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:447
verses.text: )  Here beginneth the letter of Atticus, bishop of Constantinople to the same.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:448
verses.text: To our holy lords, and rightly most blessed brethren and fellow bishops, Aurelius, Valentine, and to the other beloved ones met together in the Synod held at Carthage, Atticus the bishop.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:449
verses.text: By our son Marcellus the subdeacon, I have received with all thanksgiving the writings of your holiness, praising the Lord that I enjoyed the blessing of so many of my brethren.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:450
verses.text: O my lords and most blessed brethren, ye have written asking me to send you most accurate copies of the canons enacted at the city of Nice, the metropolis of Bithynia, by the Fathers for the exposition of the faith.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:451
verses.text: And who is there that would deny to his brethren the common faith, or the statutes decreed by the Fathers.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:452
verses.text: Wherefore by the same son of mine, Marcellus, your subdeacon, who was in great haste, I have sent to you the canons in full as they were adopted by the Fathers in the city of Nice; and I ask of you that your holy synod would have me much in your prayers.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:453
verses.text: The subscription.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:454
verses.text: May our God keep your sanctity, as we desire, most holy brethren.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:455
verses.text: Canon CXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:456
verses.text: (Continuation of the last in the Greek.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:457
verses.text: )  Here begin the examples of the Nicene Council, sent on the sixth day before the calends of December in the year 419,after the consulate of the most glorious emperor Honorius for the XIIth time, and Theodosius for the IXth time, Augustuses, to Boniface the bishop of the City of Rome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:458
verses.text: We believe in one God etc.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:459
verses.text: …the Catholic and Apostolic Church anathematizes them.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:460
verses.text: To this symbol of the faith there were also annexed copies of the statutes of the same Nicene Councils from the aforenamed pontiffs, in all respects as are contained above; which we do not think it necessary to write out here again.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:461
verses.text: Notes.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:462
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXVII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:463
verses.text: The Canons of the Synod of Nice are sent, as they were decreed by the Fathers, in accordance with your letters.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:464
verses.text: [Here follows the Nicene Creed in full.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:465
verses.text: ]            Canon CXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:466
verses.text: (Not numbered in the Greek.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:467
verses.text: )  Here beginneth the epistle of the African synod to Pope Celestine, bishop of the City of Rome.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:468
verses.text: To the lord and most beloved and our honourable brother Celestine, Aurelius, Palatinus, Antony, Totus, Servusdei, Terentius, Fortunatus, Martin, Januarius, Optatus, Ceticius, Donatus, Theasius, Vincent, Fortunatian, and the rest of us, assembled at Carthage in the General Council of Africa.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:469
verses.text: We could wish that, like as your Holiness intimated to us, in your letter sent by our fellow presbyter Leo, your pleasure at the arrival of Apiarius, so we also could send to you these writings with pleasure respecting his clearing.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:470
verses.text: Then in truth both our own satisfaction, and yours of late would be more reasonable; nor would that lately expressed by you concerning the hearing of him then to come, as well as that already past, seem hasty and inconsiderate.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:471
verses.text: Upon the arrival, then, of our holy Brother and fellow-Bishop Faustinus, we assembled a council, and believed that he was sent with that man, in order that, as he [Apiarius] had before been restored to the presbyterate by his assistance, so now he might with his exertions be cleared of the very great crimes charged against him by the inhabitants of Tabraca.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:472
verses.text: But the due course of examination in our council discovered in him such great and monstrous crimes as to overbear even Faustinus, who acted rather as an advocate of the aforementioned person than as a judge, and to prevail against what was more the zeal of a defender, than the justice of an inquirer.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:473
verses.text: For first he vehemently opposed the whole assembly, inflicting on us many injuries, under pretence of asserting the privileges of the Roman Church, and wishing that he should be received into communion by us, on the ground that your Holiness, believing him to have appealed, though unable to prove it, had restored him to communion.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:474
verses.text: But this we by no means allowed, as you will also better see by reading the acts.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:475
verses.text: After however, a most laborious inquiry carried on for three days, during which in the greatest affliction we took cognizance of various charges against him, God the just Judge, strong and long suffering, cut short by a sudden stroke both the delays of our fellow-bishop Faustinus and the evasions of Apiarius himself, by which he was endeavouring to veil his foul enormities.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:476
verses.text: For his strong and shameless obstinacy was overcome, by which he endeavoured to cover, through an impudent denial, the mire of his lusts, and God so wrought upon his conscience and published, even to the eyes of men, the secret crimes which he was already condemning in that man's heart, a very sty of wickedness, that, after his false denial he suddenly burst forth into a confession of all the crimes he was charged with, and at length convicted himself of his own accord of all infamies beyond belief, and changed to groans even the hope we had entertained, believing and desiring that he might be cleared from such shameful blots, except indeed that it was so far a relief to our sorrow, that he had delivered us from the labour of a longer inquiry, and by confession had applied some sort of remedy to his own wounds, though, lord and brother, it was unwilling, and done with a struggling conscience.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:477
verses.text: Premising, therefore, our due regards to you, we earnestly conjure you, that for the future you do not readily admit to a hearing persons coming hence, nor choose to receive to your communion those who have been excommunicated by us, because you, venerable Sir, will readily perceive that this has been prescribed even by the Nicene council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:478
verses.text: For though this seems to be there forbidden in respect of the inferior clergy, or the laity, how much more did it will this to be observed in the case of bishops, lest those who had been suspended from communion in their own Province might seem to be restored to communion hastily or unfitly by your Holiness.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:479
verses.text: Let your Holiness reject, as is worthy of you, that unprincipled taking shelter with you of presbyters likewise, and the inferior clergy, both because by no ordinance of the Fathers hath the Church of Africa been deprived of this authority, and the Nicene decrees have most plainly committed not only the clergy of inferior rank, but the bishops themselves to their own Metropolitans.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:480
verses.text: For they have ordained with great wisdom and justice, that all matters should be terminated in the places where they arise; and did not think that the grace of the Holy Spirit would be wanting to any Province, for the bishops of Christ (Sacerdotibus) wisely to discern, and firmly to maintain the right: especially since whosoever thinks himself wronged by any judgment may appeal to the council of his Province, or even to a General Council [i-e: of Africa] unless it be imagined that God can inspire a single individual with justice, and refuse it to an innumerable multitude of bishops (sacerdotum) assembled in council.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:481
verses.text: And how shall we be able to rely on a sentence passed beyond the sea, since it will not be possible to send thither the necessary witnesses, whether from the weakness of sex, or advanced age, or any other impediment? For that your Holiness should send any on your part we can find ordained by no council of Fathers.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:482
verses.text: Because with regard to what you have sent us by the same our brother bishop Faustinus, as being contained in the Nicene Council, we can find nothing of the kind in the more authentic copies of that council, which we have received from the holy Cyril our brother, Bishop of the Alexandrine Church, and from the venerable Atticus the Prelate of Constantinople, and which we formerly sent by Innocent the presbyter, and Marcellus the subdeacon through whom we received them, to Boniface the Bishop, your predecessor of venerable memory.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:483
verses.text: Moreover whoever desires you to delegate any of your clergy to execute your orders, do not comply, lest it seem that we are introducing the pride of secular dominion into the Church of Christ which exhibiteth to all that desire to see God the light of simplicity and the day of humility.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:484
verses.text: For now that the miserable Apiarius has been removed out of the Church of Christ for his horrible crimes, we feel confident respecting our brother Faustinus, that through the uprightness and moderation of your Holiness, Africa, without violating brotherly charity, will by no means have to endure him any longer.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:485
verses.text: Lord and brother, may our Lord long preserve your Holiness to pray for us.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:486
verses.text: Ancient Epitome of Canon CXXXVIII.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:487
verses.text: Those excommunicated by us, ye are not be willing to admit afterwards to communion, according to the decree of the Nicene Synod.

verses.name: Council of Carthage 3:488
verses.text: For Apiarius, who was restored by you, has resisted the Synod, and treated it with scorn, and at length has been converted and confessed himself guilty with sighs and tears.
